Airport_description: Located in the city of Nørresundby, Aalborg Airport is the third largest in Denmark and serves the city of Aalborg.
Originally built in 1946, Aarhus Airport has since been the “temporary” primary airport for the city of Aarhus, despite being located in the city of Tirstrup nearly 50 kilometers away.
Abakan International Airport is located in Abakan, Republic of Khakassia, Russia.
Opened in 1929, Albacete Airport is located on Los Llanos Air Base and serves the city of Albacete.
Opened in 1929 and still operating from its original location, Lehigh Valley International gets its airport code from its former name: Allentown–Bethlehem–Easton International.
Abilene Regional dates back to the 1930s and gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Abilene.
Félix Houphouët-Boigny International is named after the first President of Côte d’Ivoire, or Ivory Coast. While located in the town of Port-Bouët, it serves the city of Abidjan.
Opened in 1939, New Mexico’s largest airport gets its name and airport code from its home in Albuquerque.
Nnamdi Azikiwe International is named after the first Nigerian President. Its airport code comes from the city of Abuja, but unable to use ABU, they replaced the ‘U’ with the letter ‘V’.
Opened in 1934, Aberdeen International is located in the suburb of Dyce and serves the city of Aberdeen. Its three-letter code is completed with a filler letter ‘Z’.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional General Juan N. Álvarez
Airport_description: Named after Juan Álvarez, military general and interim President of Mexico, Acapulco International is an important tourist gateway for the resorts and beaches of Acapulco.
Kotoka International is named after Lieutenant General Emmanuel Kwasi Kotoka and is the only international airport in Ghana. Its airport code comes from the city it serves, Accra.
Lanzarote Airport began accepting civil traffic in 1946. It serves the island of Lanzarote and gets its airport code from the nearby city of Arrecife.
When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the U.S. Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. Nantucket Memorial, then, used other letters in its name to get ACK.
Originally built in 1942 as a naval air station, Atlantic City International is now a joint civilian and military airfield and home to the Atlantic City Air National Guard Base.
Adana Şakirpaşa Airport, located in Adana, Turkey, is the sixth-busiest airport in the country, serving 5.6 million passengers in 2016.
Formerly Haile Selassie I Airport, Addis Ababa Bole International is located in the subcity of Bole and serves the capital city of Addis Ababa.
First established in 1955, the main airport for Adelaide, Australia gets its airport code from its home in ADeLaide.
Jorge Newbery Airfield serves as the main airport for the city of Buenos Aires and is named after an Argentine aviator. Its airport code comes from its Spanish name Aeroparque Jorge Newbery.
Sochi International served as the main airport for the 22nd Winter Olympics held in Sochi in 2014. Its airport code comes from its home in the Adlersky District.
Officially opened in 1958, Ålesund Airport is located on the island of Vigra and serves the city of Ålesund.
Previously known as England Air Force Base, Alexandria International gets its three-letter code from its home in Alexandria.
A single-runway international airport in Akureyri, nothern Iceland.
With a capacity of 3 million travelers per year, Agadir – Al Massira Airport gets its airport code from the city of Agadir.
Originally opened in 1968, Augsburg Airport is located in Affing and serves the city of Augsburg.
Dedicated in 1931, Allegheny County Airport was originally designed to be Pittsburgh’s primary airport. Located in West Mifflin, it serves Allegheny County.
Located in Málaga, Costa del Sol Airport didn’t think MAL was a good option as “mal” means “bad” in Spanish. Instead, it opted to use letters from Málaga and a filler letter ‘P’.
First established as a flight school for the U.S. military, Augusta Regional has become a significant hub for the Central Savannah River Area (CSRA). Its airport code comes from the city of Augusta.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Lic. Jesús Terán Peredo
Airport_description: Jesús Terán Peredo International is named after a former governor of Aguascalientes, the city and state from which its airport code derives.
Opened in 1977, Abha Regional gets its three-letter airport code from rearranged letters in the city name of Abha.

Ajaccio Napoleon Bonaparte Airport serves as the main gateway to the island of Corsica in the Mediterranean Sea. It is located directly at sea level close to the city of Ajaccio, which is also the birthplace of Napoleon Bonaparte.
Featuring a single runway, Al-Jawf Domestic Airport serves the city of Sakakah and gets its name and airport code from the city’s alternate name, Al-Jawf.
Lengpui Airport gets its name from the nearby Lengpui Village. Its airport code comes from an alternate spelling of its home city of Aizawl: Aijal.
Officially inaugurated in 1958, Aracaju–Santa Maria Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Aracaju.
Opened in 1929, Akron Fulton International is named after longtime manager Bain Ecarius “Shorty” Fulton. The code AKR was given to Akure Airport in Nigeria, so Akron uses AKC for Akron City.
Once the site for the Mangere Aerodrome, New Zealand’s busiest airport is located in Mangere, a suburb of Auckland.
Aktobe Airport gets its three-letter code from its home city of Aktobe. It is completed with a letter ‘X’, often used as a filler letter.
Almaty International is Kazakhstan’s largest international airport. It is located 15km northeast from the city of Almaty and was formerly known as Alma-Ata Airport.
Albany International was the first municipal airport in the United States. It is the major air center for the Capital Region, northeastern New York, and western New England.
Originally named El Altet, Alicante–Elche Airport is the sixth busiest airport in Spain. Located in Elche, it serves the cities of Valencia, Murcia, and Alicante.
Opened in 1924 as Maison Blanche Airport, Houari Boumediene Airport is now named after a former President of Algeria. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Algiers.
Opened in early 1941, it is owned by the City and County of Alamosa and is named for Carl A. Bergman, a local businessman and initial supporter of the airport.
Opened in 1929 as English Field, Amarillo Airport was renamed in 2003 to honor Rick Husband, NASA astronaut who died in the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster. Its code honors the city of Amarillo.
Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International is named after India’s first Deputy Prime Minister. Its airport code honors its home in the beautiful city of Ahmedabad.
Named after Queen Alia, third wife to the late King Hussein, Jordan’s largest airport is located in Zizya, 30 km (20 mi) south of the capital city of Amman.

Pattimura Airport is named after Thomas Matulessy, also known as Kapitan Pattimura, Indonesian soldier and national hero. Its airport code comes from the city of Ambon plus a ‘Q’, often used as a filler letter.
The name “Schiphol” came from the nearby Fort Schiphol, which translates to “ship grave” in English. Its airport code honors the city of Amsterdam.
In 2009, Anchorage International was renamed to honor U.S. Senator Ted Stevens, but its airport code still honors its home in Anchorage.
Angoulême – Cognac International is located between Brie and Champniers and serves the city of Angoulême.
Antwerp International is a small scale airport serving Belgium’s second biggest city. Its airport code refers directly to the city of Antwerp.
Andahuaylas Airport is the only airport in the Apurímac Region that serves commercial flights. Its three-letter code comes from the city of Andahuaylas.

Built in 1942 by the U.S. Army as Coolidge Airfield, V. C. Bird International was renamed in 1985 in honor of the country’s first Prime Minister, Vere Cornwall Bird Sr. Its airport code comes from the island’s name, Antigua.
Raffaello Sanzio Airport is named after the famous Renaissance artist, internationally known as Raphael. Located in Falconara Marittima, it serves the city of Ancona, Italy.
Centennial Airport serves the Denver-Aurora metro area in Colorado. It is located in the town of Dove Valley and was previously known Arapahoe County Airport.
Faleolo Airport was built during World War II by the U.S. Navy. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Apia and the country’s name at the time of its designation, Western Samoa.
King Hussein International is located within a 15-mile radius of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, and Israel. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Aqaba, Jordan.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Alférez Alfredo Rodríguez Ballón
Airport_description: Alfredo Rodríguez Ballón International shares its name with the Peruvian aviator. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Arequipa.
Stockholm’s airport is named Arlanda, a made-up word combining “Arland”, another name for the nearby parish of Ärlinghundra, and “landa”, Swedish verb meaning “to land.”

The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Watertown International opted, then, to use other letters from Watertown.
Opened in 1994 and formerly named after Saparmyrat Niyazov, Turkmenistan’s first President, Ashgabat International gets its airport code from the capital city of Ashgabat.
Officially dedicated in 1958, Aspen–Pitkin County Airport is also called Sardy Field, named after Commissioner Thomas J. Sardy. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Aspen.
Formerly known as Yohannes IV Airport, Asmara International was nearly destroyed during World War II and was rebuilt in the 1950s. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Asmara.
Silvio Pettirossi International is named after Silvio Pettirossi, local aviator and pioneer. Located in the city of Luque, its aiport code comes from the city it serves, Asunción.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Comandante FAP Germán Arias Graziani
Airport_description: Germán Arias Graziani Airport serves the city of Huaraz, but gets its three-letter code from the nearby village of Anta.

Eleftherios Venizelos Airport is named after the Cretan political leader and Prime Minister of Greece who pushed the development of Greek aviation. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Athens.
The Hartsfield-Jackson Airport honors former mayors Maynard Jackson and William B. Hartsfield. The airport code honors Atlanta and has become the city’s beloved nickname.

Airport_name: Sri Guru Ram Das Jee International Airport
Airport_description: Sri Guru Ram Das Jee International is named after Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru and founder of the city of Amritsar. Its code is completed by the letter ‘Q’, often used as a filler letter.
Dedicated in 1965 and previously named Outagamie County Regional, Appleton International is located in the town of Greenville and serves the city of Appleton, Wisconsin.
Queen Beatrix International is named after Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands, former Queen and head of state. Located in the capital city of Oranjestad, it serves the island of Aruba.
In 1982, Abu Dhabi International replaced Al Bateen Airport as the primary airport for the city of Abu Dhabi.
Once the location for Bergstrom Air Force Base (BSM), Austin-Bergstrom Airport opened in 1999 and took the airport code AUS from Mueller Airport which closed that same year.
Opened in 1961, Asheville Regional is located near the town of Fletcher and serves the city of Asheville.
Granted “international” status in 1975, Wilkes-Barre/Scranton International serves the cities of Wilkes-Barre and Scranton, but is located in the city of Avoca, Pennsylvania.
Ahvaz International gets its three-letter code from its home in Ahvaz, alternately spelled Ahwaz.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Coronel FAP Alfredo Mendívil Duarte
Airport_description: Alfredo Mendívil Duarte Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Ayacucho, Peru.
Antalya Airport primarily serves tourists visiting Turkey’s Mediterranean beaches. Its three-letter code is completed by rearranged letters from its home city of Antalya.
Formerly named after 1st Lt. Charles Williams of the U.S. Army Air Corps, Phoenix-Mesa Gateway is the lucky airport whose airport code honors its home state of Arizona.

The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Kalamazoo/Battle Creek International opted, then, to use other letters from Kalamazoo.
Located on Muharraq Island, Bahrain Airport became the first international airport in the Persian Gulf in 1932. It serves the entire country of Bahrain.
Batman Airport is a civil-military airport serving the city of Batman in Batman ili, Turkey.
Dedicated in 1981, Ernesto Cortissoz International is named after Ernesto Cortissoz, Colombian aviation pioneer. It is located in the suburb of Soledad and serves the city of Barranquilla.
Chafei Amsei Airport is used for general aviation and gets its three-letter code from the city of Barretos.
This small but scenic airport is located in the university town of Blacksburg, Virginia.
Barcelona’s first airfield was built in 1916, but a new location in El Prat was chosen in 1918. The airport now uses the code BCN which stands for Barcelona.

Started as Kindley Field, a joint U.S. Army Air Force and Royal Air Force base, L.F. Wade International was renamed in 2007 after the Progressive Labour Party leader. Its airport code honors its home in Bermuda.
Bird Island Airport has a grass runway and serves travelers jumping between islands in the Seychelles. Its airport code comes from its home on Bird Island.
Originally a National Guard air base during World War II, Bradley International is named after U.S. Air Force Lieutenant Eugene M. Bradley.

Husein Sastranegara International was built by Dutch settlers and named after Husein Sastranegara, aviator from West Java. Its airport code comes from an old spelling of the city of Bandung: BanDOeng.
Formerly known as Papola Casale Airport, Brindisi - Salento Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in Brindisi.
Located in the village of Balivanich, Benbecula Airport serves the islands of Benbecula, North Uist, and South Uist off the coast of Scotland.
Laurence G. Hanscom Field is named after a local aviator who was killed in a plane crash in 1941. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Bedford.
Previously known as Belgrade Airport or Surčin Airport, it was renamed in 2006 in honor of Serbian scientist and inventor Nikola Tesla. It is the busiest airport in the former Yugoslavia.
Júlio Cezar Ribeiro International is named after Júlio Cezar Ribeiro de Sousa, Brazilian inventor of the glider balloon. Its airport code comes from the city of Belém.
Finally opening in fall of 2020 (nine years late), Berlin Brandenburg Airport’s three-letter code honors the city of Berlin.
The Brest Bretagne Airport originated as two airship hangars in Guipavas in 1917 and was formerly known as the Brest Guipavas Airport.
Located in the suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon’s only commercial airport gets its three-letter airport code from the French spelling of Beirut: Beyrouth.

Western Nebraska Regional is also referred to as William B. Heilig Field, named after a World War II flight instructor and former airport manager. Its airport code comes from its home city and former name of Scottsbluff Army Airfield.

Airport_name: King County International Airport / Boeing Field
Airport_description: King County International is located in Seattle, Washington and is also known as Boeing Field, named after William E. Boeing, founder of The Boeing Company.
In 1957, Meadows Field Airport was named after Cecil Meadows, former Army pilot and Kern County Director of Airports from 1935–1957. Located in Oildale, it serves the city of Bakersfield.
Formerly named and commonly still called Aldergrove Airport, Belfast International is located between the villages of Killead and Aldergrove. It is the busiest airport in Northern Ireland.
Palonegro International is named for the nearby area where the Battle of Palonegro took place during the Thousand Days War. Its airport code comes from the city it serves, Bucaramanga.
Grantley Adams International is named after the founder of the Barbados Labour Party. Located in the Seawell area of Bridgetown, its airport code stands for Bridgetown International.

Opened in 1955, Bergen Airport is located in the village of Flesland and is the second busiest airport in Norway. Its airport code comes from Bergen and the ‘O’ could come from Norway, but is likely a filler letter.
Originally known as Godfrey Field, Bangor International was an army air field during and after World War II. Its airport code comes from its home in Bangor.

Baghdad Airport was formerly named after Saddam Hussein and used the code SDA. When the named changed, its airport code changed to BGW, which previously referred to all Baghdad airports. The ‘W’ is a filler letter.

Airport_name: Aeroporto di Bergamo-Orio al Serio Il Caravaggio
Airport_description: Il Caravaggio International is named after the famous Baroque painter. It is located in the comune of Orio al Serio, near the city of Bergamo. The ‘Y’ in BGY likely comes from Lombardy or Italy.
Opened in 1983, George Best Belfast City Airport was renamed in 2006 in honor of the Northern Irish footballer George Best. It was originally known as Belfast Harbour Airport, located in County Down.
Birmingham-Shuttlesworth International shares its name with Alabama civil rights activist Fred Shuttlesworth, but it gets its airport code from its home in Birmingham.
Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Previously Elmdon Airport, Birmingham Airport’s name gives us the first two letters plus that helpful ‘X’.
Opened in 1928, Billings Municipal was renamed to Billings Logan Field in 1957 after Dick Logan, former airport manager. In 1971 it became Billings Logan International.
Opened for passenger travel in 1948, Bilbao Airport serves the Basque Country and northern Spain from the city of Bilbao.
Renamed in 2006, Rocky Mountain Metropolitan Airport serves the Denver area and gets its airport code from the nearby town of Broomfield in Jefferson County.
The only airport in The Gambia, Banjul International is sometimes called Yundum Airport. Its three-letter code comes from the city of Banjul.
Bujumbura International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in Bujumbura, the capital city of Burundi.
Guanajuato International is located in the city of Guanajuato and gets its airport code from the region of Bajío, Mexico.
Lake Brooks Seaplane Base is a seaplane landing area on Naknek Lake in Katmai National Park. Its airport code comes from the nearby Brooks Falls.
Kota Kinabalu International is Malaysia’s second-busiest airport. Its airport code comes from its location on Borneo and in the city of Kota Kinabalu.
Suvarnabhumi Airport was named by King Bhumibol Adulyadej after the mythical golden kingdom said to be located in Southeast Asia. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Bangkok.
Home to the Cleveland National Air Show, Burke Lakefront was opened in 1947 on the shore of Lake Erie and is named after then mayor Thomas A. Burke.
Opened in 1974, Sénou International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the capital city of Bamako.
Bellingham International was used by the Fourth Air Force during World War II. Commercial service to Bellingham began in the mid 1980s.
Located on the coast of Lancashire, Blackpool Airport was formerly known as Squires Gate Airport. Its airport code comes from the city of Blackpool.

Billund Airport was once a private runway owned by Godtfred Kirk Christiansen, son to LEGO founder Ole Kirk Christiansen. Located in Billund, it served the LEGO factory and now serves nearby Legoland.
Named after Guglielmo Marconi, Italian inventor and Nobel laureate, Bologna Airport serves the city of Bologna. Its code is completed by the letter ‘Q’, often used as a filler letter.
Kempegowda International was renamed in 2013 to honor the city’s founder, Kempe Gowda I. Its airport code comes from a former spelling of Bengaluru: Bangalore.
Opened in 1936, Stockholm Bromma Airport serves the city of Stockholm and is located in the borough of Bromma.
Previously know as Bloomington/Normal Airport, Central Illinois Regional was renamed in 1996 to reflect its central location. Its airport code honors its home in Bloomington.
With a single functional runway, Buon Ma Thuot Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in Buon Ma Thuot, Vietnam.
Nashville International was originally named after Colonel Harry S. Berry. Codes with first letter ‘N’ were reserved for the U.S. Navy, so it used Berry Field Nashville to get BNA.
Bandar Abbas International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Bandar Abbas.
Opened in 1988, Brisbane Airport replaced Eagle Farm Airport as the primary airport serving the city of Brisbane in Queensland.

Originally built in 1976, Banja Luka International is located in the village of Mahovljani, but serves the ctiy of Banja Luka. Its three-letter code is completed by an ‘X’, often used as a filler letter.
Opened during World War II and located on the islet of Motu Mute, Bora Bora Airport gets its three-letter code from the island it serves, Bora Bora.
Started as an airfield in 1917, Bordeaux-Mérignac Airport gets its three-letter code from the city it serves, Bordeaux.
El Dorado International may be named after the mythical city of gold, but its airport code comes from its home in Bogotá.
Started during World War II, RAF Hurn was renamed in 1969 to Bournemouth Airport after the nearby town in southern England.
Originally named (and often still called) Gowen Field, Boise Airport honored U.S. Army 1st Lieutenant Paul R. Gowen. Its airport code honors its home in Boise.
The Mumbai airport was previously named Sahar International, but it gets its three-letter code from the city’s former English name, Bombay, changed in 1995.
Opened in 1945, Flamingo International is located in the city of Kralendijk and serves the island of Bonaire.
Formerly Jeffery Field, Logan Airport was renamed in 1943 to honor Edward Lawrence Logan, U.S. Army Lt. General and MA state representative. Its airport code honors its home in Boston.

Airport_name: Bandar Udara Internasional Sultan Aji Muhammad Sulaiman
Airport_description: Sultan Aji Muhammad Sulaiman International, formerly Sepinggan Airport, is the busiest airport in Kalimantan. It serves the nearby city of Balikpapan.
Formerly Southeast Texas Regional, Jack Brooks Regional was renamed to honor former U.S. Representative Jack Brooks. It serves the cities of Beaumont and Port Arthur, Texas
Biggin Hill Airport was originally opened by the Royal Flying Corps during World War I. It gets its three-letter code from the town of Biggin Hill plus a ‘Q’, often used as a filler letter.
Opened in 1940, Barreiras Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Barreiras.
Opened in 1920 and originally called Neuenlander Feld, Bremen Airport serves as a starting point for commercial pilot careers at Lufthansa.
Formerly Brownsville Army Airfield, Brownsville/South Padre Island International gets its three-letter code from its home in Brownsville, Texas.
Built in the 1950s, Brno–Tuřany Airport gets its airport code from the city of Brno, plus a helpful ‘Q’ as a filler letter.
Opened in 1936, Barra Airport is located at the north tip of the island of Barra in the Outer Hebrides, Scotland. It is the only airport in the world using a beach as its runway.
Used as RAF Lulsgate Bottom during World War II, Bristol Airport is located at Lulsgate Bottom in North Somerset and serves the city of Bristol.
Built during World War II and originally called Fliegerhorst Melsbroek, Belgium’s largest airport is located between Zaventem and Machelen, northeast of Brussels.
Wiley Post–Will Rogers Memorial Airport honors the late entertainer Will Rogers and aviator Wiley Post whose plane crashed nearby in 1935. Its airport code honors its home in Barrow.

Airport_name: Aeroporto Internacional de Brasília–Pres. Juscelino Kubitschek
Airport_description: Renamed in 1999 to honor former President Juscelino Kubitschek de Oliveira, Brasília International gets its airport code from its home in the capital city of Brasília, Brazil.

EuroAirport Basel-Mulhouse-Freiburg has two IATA codes (MLH is the other one). It is actually located in Saint-Louis, France but is one of only a few airports in the world operated jointly by two countries, in this case France and Switzerland.

Airport_name: Bandar Udara Internasional Sultan Iskandar Muda
Airport_description: The Sultan Iskander Muda International serves the area near Banda Aceh. Its airport code refers to the nearby subdistricts of Blang Bintang and Jantho.
Bert Mooney Airport in Butte, Montana is named for the first pilot to fly mail into Yellowstone National Park. It opened in 1926 as Butte Municipal Airport.
Also known as Ryan Field, Baton Rouge Metropolitan gets its three-letter code from its home in Baton Rouge.
M. R. Štefánik Airport, also called Bratislava Airport, was renamed in 1993 after General Milan Rastislav Štefánik, whose aircraft crashed near Bratislava in 1919.
In 1920, Burlington Municipal Airport opened, honoring and serving the city of Burlington, Vermont.
Still called “Ferihegy” for the surrounding neighborhood, Budapest’s airport was renamed in 2011 to honor Hungarian composer Ferenc Liszt.
Opened in 1926 as Buffalo Municipal, Buffalo Niagara International was rebuilt and renamed in 1997 to honor the oft-visited Niagara Falls.

Bob Hope Airport has gone by six names since its opening in 1930. It was renamed most recently in 2003 to honor entertainer Bob Hope. Like two of its former names, its code refers to its location in the Los Angeles suburb of BURbank.
Bathpalathang Airport is located in the city of Jakar. Its three-letter airport code comes from the Bumthang District.
Built during the 1930s, Beauvais-Tillé Airport is located in Tillé and serves Beauvais. It is often referred to as Paris-Beauvais Airport.
Opened in 1973, Atlas Brasil Cantanhede International is named after Atlas Brasil Cantanhede, Brazilian aviation pioneer. Its three-letter code comes from its home in Boa Vista, Brazil.
Originally Rabil Airport, it was renamed in 2011 to honor Cape Verde’s first president, Aristides Pereira. Its code comes from its home on the island of Boa Vista, Cape Verde.

Located directly at the German Federal Aviation Office and the German Aerospace Center, the Braunschweig Airport mainly serves research flights as well as private business flights for the Volkswagen group, which is a major shareholder.

Originally Friendship International (perhaps the best airport name ever), Baltimore/Washington International was renamed in 1973 and again in 2005 to honor Thurgood Marshall, former U.S. Supreme Court justice.
Opened in 1974, Brunei International serves the country of Brunei and its capital city of Bandar Seri Begawan.
Originally built in 1964 as a military training center, Beja Airport began serving civilian traffic to Beja in 2011. Its code is completed by the letter ‘Y’, often used as a filler letter.

Airport_name: Philip S. W. Goldson International Airport
Airport_description: Philip S. W. Goldson International is named after Philip Stanley Wilberforce Goldson, former Belizean politician. Its airport code comes from its home in Belize City.
In 2005, Gallatin Field was renamed to Bozeman Yellowstone International in honor of the famous national park.
Maya-Maya Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in Brazzaville, the capital city of Republic of Congo.
Built in 1940 and originally named Lexington County Airport, Columbia Metropolitan gets its airport code from the nearby city of Cayce.
Originally built in 1962, Ca Mau Airport serves the city of Cà Mau, Vietnam. The ‘H’ comes from Ho Chi Minh City, the only destination the airport serves.
Originally built during World War II and known as Payne Airfield, Egypt’s busiest airport serves the capital city of Cairo.
Dedicated in 1946, Akron–Canton Airport is actually located in the city of Green, Ohio. Its airport code comes from the nearby cities of Canton and Akron.
Guangzhou Baiyun International opened in 2004 as a replacement for the 72-year-old airport with the same name. Its airport code comes from Guangzhou’s former English name: Canton.
Jorge Wilstermann International is named after a famous Bolivian aviator. Its aiport code honors the city of Cochabamba.
Cambridge Airport, briefly known as Marshall Airport Cambridge UK, originally opened in 1938. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Cambridge.
Originally an airstrip built in the 1920s, Canberra International now serves the cities of Canberra and Queanbeyan in New South Wales.
Sometimes called Salvaza Airport, Carcassonne Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in Carcassonne, France.
Calicut International is named after the city of Kozhikode, Calicut in English. Its code is completed by the letter ‘J’, often used as a filler letter.
Built during World War II, Cocos (Keeling) Islands Airport is located near Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean and serves the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands.
Opened in 1968, Carriel Sur International is located in the city of Concepción, Chile.
Often called just “Maiquetía” by locals, Simón Bolívar International is named after the former Venezuelan president. Its airport code stands for Caracas.

Airport_name: Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose International Airport
Airport_description: Previously Dum Dum Aiport, Netjai Subhas Chandra Bose International was renamed in 1995 to honor the Indian freedom fighter. Its airport code comes from a former spelling of Kolkata: Calcutta.
Cedar City Regional gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Cedar City, Utah.
Renamed and officially opened in 1974, France’s largest airport is named after Charles de Gaulle, former President and founder of the French Fifth Republic.
First opened in 1956, Mactan–Cebu International is located in Lapu-Lapu City and serves greater Metro Cebu.
With a history dating back to the 1930s, Chelyabinsk Airport began serving international passengers in 1994. Its airport code comes from the city of Chelyabinsk.
Inaugurated in 1998, Cabo Frio International is privately operated and serves the city of Cabo Frio, Brazil.
Located in the city of Bryan, Coulter Field has a long history of sport parachuting. Many have skydived at Coulter Field, include Texas Governor Rick Perry and former U.S. President George H.W. Bush.
São Paulo/Congonhas Airport opened in 1936 and is named after the neighborhood where it’s located, Vila Congonhas.

Soekarno–Hatta International serves the capital city of Jakarta and honors Indonesia’s first president and vice-president. It receives its code from the Cengkareng district in the city of Tangerang, where it’s located.
Cologne Bonn Airport is christened after Konrad Adenauer, Germany’s first Chancellor following World War II, but its airport code comes from its home in Cologne.
Zhengzhou Xinzheng International is the principal airport serving Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan province, China. Its IATA code ‘CGO’ is derived from Zhengzhou’s former Romanization, Chengchow.
Opened in 1953, Campo Grande International is located in the municipality of Antônio João and is often called Antônio João Airport. It serves the city of Campo Grande.
Opened in 1930 as Lovell Field, Chattanooga Metropolitan Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Chattanooga.
Opened in 1940, Christchurch International became New Zealand’s first international airport in 1950. Located in the suburb of Harewood, its airport code comes from the city of Christchurch.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Teniente FAP Jaime Montreuil Morales
Airport_description: Jaime Montreuil Morales Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Chimbote.
Formerly an air base, the airport is now an airline training and maintenance facility located near the town of Châteauroux in central France.
Used as a military airfield during World War II and the Korean War, Charleston International’s airport code comes from its home in Charleston, South Carolina.
Often called just Rome Ciampino Airport, G.B. Pastine International is named after World War I aviator, Giovan Battista Pastine. It serves the city of Rome and is located in Ciampino.
Before being renamed in 1997, The Eastern Iowa Airport was known as Cedar Rapids Municipal.
In its current location since 1963, Shymkent International gets its three-letter code from the city’s former name of Chimkent.
Formerly the Kincheloe Air Force Base, Chippewa County International is located 15 miles south of the central business district of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Capitán FAP José Abelardo Quiñones Gonzáles
Airport_description: José Abelardo Quiñones Gonzáles International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Chiclayo. The code is completed by an ‘X’, often used as a filler letter.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Mayor General FAP Armando Revoredo Iglesias
Airport_description: Armando Revoredo Iglesias Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Cajamarca.
Jeju International is South Korea’s second largest airport. Its three-letter code comes from the McCune-Reischauer romanization of Jeju: Cheju.
Originally opened in 1935 as Tri-County Airport, North Central West Virginia Airport is actually located in the the city of Bridgeport, but is most associated with the city it serves: Clarksburg.
Opened in 1990, Chongqing Jiangbei International replaced the older Baishiyi Airport. Its three-letter code comes from the city’s former English name: Chungking.
Formerly Gbessia Airport, Conakry International is the primary airport in Guinea. Its three-letter code comes from the capital city of Conakry.
McClellan-Palomar Airport is located in northwest San Diego county and is named after George McClellan, local aviator and civic leader.  Its airport code comes from its city of CarLsbaD.
Hopkins International is named after former mayor William R. Hopkins. Its airport code honors its home in Cleveland.
Founded in 1932, Cluj Avram Iancu International is named after Romanian revolutionary Avram Iancu. Its airport code comes from its home city of Cluj-Napoca.
Opened in 1940, Easterwood Airport is named after U.S. Navy Lt. Jesse L. Easterwood. It is owned by Texas A&M University and is located in the city of College Station.
Formerly Palmaseca International, Cali’s airport is named after Alfonso Bonilla Aragón, local civic leader and journalist. Its airport code comes from an early nickname: Calipuerto.
Formerly Morris Field Air Base, Douglas Airport was renamed in 1954 to honor former mayor Ben Elbert Douglas, Sr., but its airport code honors its home in Charlotte.
Bandaranaike International is named after former Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike and is one of the busiest hub airports in South Asia. Its airport code honors the city it serves, Colombo.
Opened in 1929, Port Columbus is now the second busiest airport in Ohio. Its three-letter airport code comes from its original name Columbus Municipal Hangar.
Dedicated in 1945, Willard Airport is named after former University of Illinois president, Arthur Cutts Willard. Its airport code comes from the area it serves, Champaign-Urbana.
Originally known as Berrechid Airfield, Mohammed V International’s airport code comes from its full name and location: Casablanca Mohammed V International Airport, Nouaceur.
Houghton Country Memorial gets its airport code from the Canadian Michigan Exchange, an agreement between Canada, the U.S., Michigan, and Houghton County, through which the airport was constructed.
Named after former Brazilian President-elect Tancredo Neves, the airport that serves the Belo Horizonte metro area is located in the municipality of Confins.
Cognac – Châteaubernard Air Base is home to the pilot training school, Ecole de Pilotage de l'Armee de l'Air. Its three-letter code is rearranged letters from Cognac.
Kannur International, located in Mattannur, serves the city of Kannur (anglicized Cannanore) in Kerala, India.
Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Chiang Mai International, a major gateway to the north of Thailand, uses that helpful ‘X’ in its airport code.
Cochin International is located in the city of Kochi, previously known as Cochin. Its airport code pulls letters from the new name, Kochi, but reverses them.
Cotonou International is officially named after Beninese Cardinal Bernardin Gantin. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of Cotonou.
The third largest airport in Argentina, Córdoba International is also called Ingeniero Aeronáutico Ambrosio L.V. Taravella Airport. It gets its three-letter code from the city of Córdoba.
In operation since 1927, the COlorado Springs Airport is the second busiest airport in Colorado.
Located in the small town of Kastrup and founded in 1925, Copenhagen Airport is one of the oldest civil airports in the world.
Opened in 1954 to replace Wingfield Aerodrome, Africa’s third busiest airport is located in the city of Cape Town, South Africa.
Presidente João Suassuna Airport gets its three-letter code from Campina Grande. The ‘V’ could come from Vila Nova da Rainha, the city’s former name, but is likely a filler letter.
Built at great expense, Ciudad Real Central Airport was previously known as Don Quijote Airport and South Madrid Airport, but now sits unused.
Originally established as Clark Air Base by the U.S. Army in 1903, Clark International is named after Major Harold M. Clark. It was known as Diosdado Macapagal International from 2003 until 2012.
Brussels South Charleroi International started as a flying school in 1919. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Charleroi.
Corpus Christi International opened a new six-gate terminal named Hayden W. Head Terminal in 2002. It is city-owned and available for public-use just west of Corpus Christi, in Nueces County, Texas.
Yeager Airport is named after U.S. Army Brigadier General Chuck Yeager, but its airport code honors its home in Charleston, West Virginia.
Also known as Vincenzo Bellini Airport after the famous opera composer, Catania–Fontanarossa Airport was the region’s first airport, built in 1924.
Rafael Núñez International is named after the former Colombian president who wrote the verses for the country’s national anthem. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Cartagena.

Opened in 1991, New Chitose Airport replaced the original Chitose Airport. It serves the Sapporo area and at first had the three-letter code of SPK. Its current code comes from its name and the nearby city of Chitose.

Shuangliu Airport opened in 1938 as a supplementary airfield during World War II and is now one of the busiest airports in China. Its airport code is derived from the city’s former English name: Chengtu.
Often called Culiacán Airport, Bachigualato Federal International is named after Bachigualato, the neighborhood where it’s located. Its airport code comes from Culiacán, the city it serves.
Cancún International is Mexico’s second busiest airport, but serves the most international traffic. Its three-letter code comes from the city of Cancún.
Alejandro Velasco Astete International is named after the Peruvian pilot first to cross the Andes in 1925. It serves the city of Cusco, often spelled Cuzco.
Courchevel Altiport (a term used to describe mountainous aerodomes in the French Alps) serves Courchevel ski resort. Its three-letter code comes from Courchevel, France.
Serving the greater Cincinnati metro area, Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky’s airport code comes from the nearby city of Covington.
Opened in 2005, Corvo Airport is located in Vila do Corvo on the island of Corvo. The letter ‘U’ is a phonetic replacement for the ‘O’ in Corvo.

Airport_name: Aeroporto Internacional de Curitiba - Afonso Pena
Airport_description: Built in 1944 for the Brazilian Air Force, Afonso Pena International is named after Brazil’s 6th president. With the codes CUR and CUB already taken, Curitiba subbed a ‘W’ for the ‘U’.
Started as a satellite aerodrome during World War II, Cardiff Airport gets its airport code from its home in Cardiff, Wales.

Airport_name: Sân bay Quốc tế Cam Ranh
Airport_description: Originally built by the U.S. Navy during the Vietnam War, Cam Ranh International serves Khanh Hoa but is located on Cam Ranh Bay. Its code is completed by an ‘X’, often used as a filler letter.
Started in 1930 as Sholtz Field, Daytona Beach International evolved from an uncommonly successful beach airport. Located next to Daytona International Speedway, it serves the city of Daytona Beach.
In 2010, Hazrat Shahjalal International was renamed to honor the Sufi saint Shah Jalal. Its airport code comes from a former spelling for the city of Dhaka: Dacca.

Airport_name: Sân bay Quốc tế Đà Nẵng
Airport_description: Da Nang International is located in Da Nang, the largest city in central Vietnam. Its code’s last letter likely comes from Quang Nam-Đa Nang, the province Da Nang belonged to before becoming an independent municipality in 1997.
Founded and named in 1917, Love Field honors U.S. Army pilot Moss L. Love. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Dallas.
Inaugurated in the 1970s, Damascus International get its airport code from its home in the capital city of Damascus.
Renamed in 2006, Julius Nyerere International honors Tanzania’s first president. It was previously named Dar es Salaam International after its home city.

Airport_name: James M. Cox Dayton International Airport
Airport_description: In 1952, Dayton Municipal was renamed to honor James M. Cox, former governor of Ohio. Its airport code honors its home in Dayton.
Dubuque Regional features two runways and serves as a general aviation and commercial airport. Its three-letter code comes from its home city of Dubuque.
Opened in 1962, Dubrovnik Airport is located in the village of Čilipi and serves the city of Dubrovnik.
In 1998, Washington National Airport was renamed to honor former U.S. President Ronald Reagan. Its airport code honors its home in District of Columbia.
Originally opened in the 1930s, Debrecen International gets its airport code from its home in the city of Debrecen.
Dehradun International is located 25km from Dehradun. It’s also known as the Air Gateway of Garhwal and is important for tourism in Uttarakhand.
Previously known as Palam Aiport, Indira Gandhi International was renamed in 1986 to honor the former Indian prime minister. Its airport code honors its home in Delhi.
Until 1995, Stapleton International Airport served the Denver area with airport code DEN. When Stapleton closed, the new airport switched from DVX to DEN.
Formerly Detroit City Airport, Coleman A. Young International is named after Coleman Young who served as mayor from 1974 to 1994. Its three-letter code honors the city of Detroit.
For decades Dallas and Fort Worth ran competing airports, but in 1969 construction finally began on a joint airport to serve the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
Presidente Nicolau Lobato International is named after East-Timorese national hero Nicolau dos Reis Lobato. Its three-letter airport code comes from the capital city of Dili.
Dien Bien Phu Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Dien Bien Phu, Vietnam.
Formerly known as Dakar Yoff Airport, Léopold Sédar Senghor International is now named after the first President of Senegal. Located in Yoff, it serves the capital city of Dakar.
Douala International is the busiest airport in Cameroon. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of Douala.
Dalian Zhoushuizi International is located in Liaoning Province and serves the city of Dalian, China.
Opened in 1930 as Williamson–Johnson Municipal, Duluth International was renamed in 1961. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Duluth.
Located in Đức Trọng District, Lien Khuong Airport is the largest of four airports in the Central Highlands region. Its code comes from Dalat International.
Officially opened in 1965, Russia’s busiest airport serves the capital city of Moscow. It is actually located in the nearby town of Domodedovo.

Originally Bangkok International, Don Mueang Airport was renamed when Suvarnabhumi Airport opened in 2006. It gave up its BKK code and received a new one derived from Don Mueang and carrying over the ‘K’ from the old code.
Opened in 1999, King Fahd International is the world’s largest airport by land area. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Dammam.
Opened in 1963, Dundee Airport gets its airport code from Dundee, Scotland’s fourth largest city.
Opened in 1943, Dnipropetrovsk International Airport is located 15 km southeast from the center of the city which gave it the name and the code - Dnipropetrovsk.
Dinard–Pleurtuit–Saint-Malo Airport serves the city of Saint-Malo, but gets its three-letter airport code from the nearby commune of Dinard.
Often called “New Doha Airport,” Hamad International opened in May of 2014, replacing Doha International Airport as the primary airport for Qatar’s capital city.
Formerly named Melville Hall, Douglas–Charles Airport was renamed in 2014 to honor former Prime Ministers Rosie Douglas and Pierre Charles. It is the primary airport in Dominica.
Ngurah Rai International serves the tourist destination of Bali and is named for I Gusti Ngurah Rai, national hero of Indonesia. Its airport code comes from Denpasar, the capital of the island.

In 1945, Darwin Airport began serving non-military passengers and currently still shares a runway with RAAF Base Darwin. The airport is named after its city which honors famous naturalist Charles Darwin.
Robin Hood Airport is named after the legendary outlaw of English folklore. Its airport code comes from the rest of its name, Doncaster Sheffield Airport.
Des Moines Airport was renamed “International” in 1986 to promote the presence of the U.S. Customs Service at the airport. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Des Moines.
Initially located in the suburb of Brackel, the airport serving the eastern Rhine-Ruhr area was moved to the city of Dortmund after World War II.
Shreveport Downtown Airport serves the city of Shreveport along with Shreveport Regional (SHV). Its airport code comes from its close proximty to the city’s downtown.
During World War II Detroit’s airport was known as Romulus Field, but in 1947 it was renamed to Detroit-Wayne Major Airport.
Opened in 1940, Ireland’s busiest airport is located in its capital city of Dublin.
Built in 1962, Dunedin International is colloquially known as Momona Airport. It is known for its “Southern Man” sculpture, reputed to bring good luck to travelers.
In 1998, Rhine Ruhr Airport was renamed to Düsseldorf International, but dropped the ‘International’ in 2013.
Francisco Bangoy International is named after Francisco Bangoy who donated the land on which the airport sits. Its airport code comes from its home in Davao City.
Opened in 2010, Al Maktoum International is named after Sheikh Maktoum, former Prime Minister of the UAE. It is part of Dubai World Central, a residential and commercial complex.
When Dubai International opened in 1960, the airport code DUB was already in use by Dublin, Ireland. Dubai subbed an ‘X’ for the U, making its unique airport code of DXB.
Opened in 1930, Danbury Municipal is a two-runway airport in Connecticut. Its airport code comes from Danbury, with an added ‘X’ as a filler letter once codes switched from two letters to three.
Built in 1924, Dushanbe International was the first airport in Tajikistan. Until 1929, the city of Dushanbe was known in Russian as Dyushambe, explaining its three-letter code of DYU.
Dzaoudzi-Pamandzi International is the only airport in Mayotte, located on the island of Pamanzi and serving the commune of Dzaoudzi.
San Sebastián Airport is actually located in the municipality of Hondarribia, but gets its three-letter code from the city of San Sebastián.

The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Pangborn Memorial, located in the city of Wenatchee, opted for other letters to form EAT.
Constructed in the late 1920s, Entebbe International is the primary international airport in Uganda. It serves the cities of Entebbe and Kampala.
Featuring the tenth longest runway in the world, Erbil International opened its doors in 2010 next door to the original Erbil airport, built during the 1970s.

Originally the airport wanted the three-letter code TFB for “The Florida Beaches”, but it was already taken. When going through a list of available codes, the selection group joked ECP could stand for “Everyone Can Party” and it stuck.
Previously the location for Turnhouse Aerodrome and RAF Turnhouse airfield, Scotland’s busiest airport is located in the city of Edinburgh.
EGC is located south-southeast of Bergerac, a commune of the Dordogne department (formerly the Périgord province) in the Aquitaine region of France.
Eagle County Regional is sometimes called Vail/Eagle Airport, serving the ski resorts in Vail and Beaver Creek. Its airport code comes from its home in Eagle County.
Eindhoven Airport is also a military airbase, hosting the European Air Transport Command and the Movement Coordination Centre Europe. Its airport code comes from its home in Eindhoven.
Built in 1929 as Standard Airport, El Paso International gets its three-letter code from its home city of El Paso.
Originally a Royal Air Force station, East Midlands Airport is located in Castle Donington in the East Midlands of England.
Originally opened in 1931, Enschede Airport Twente no longer serves military or passenger flights. Traffic is limited to regional flying clubs for recreational use.
The airport is named after the late Akanu Ibiam (1906-1995), a medical doctor and statesman who hailed from Afikpo in Ebonyi State. Its code honors its home in Enugu.
Originally opened in 1932, Olaya Herrera Airport is named after and gets its three-letter code from former Colombian president, Enrique Olaya Herrera.
Also known as Tom Ridge Field, Erie International is a public airport serving the city of Erie, Pennsylvania.
Esenboğa International serves the city of Ankara, but gets its name and three-letter code from the nearby village of Esenboğa which means “Windflowing Bull.”
Eugene Airport is also known as Mahlon Sweet Field, named after Mahlon Sweet, an early supporter of the airport’s construction. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of Eugene.

Originally Golden Rock Airport, F. D. Roosevelt Airport was renamed in 1946. It serves tourists to the dormant volcano “The Quill” and gets its code from Sint Eustatius, completed with an ‘X’, often used as a filler letter.
Armenia’s busiest airport get its name from its home in Zvartnots, but its airport code comes from the nearby capital city of Yerevan.
When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the U.S. Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. Newark, then, used the other letters in its name to make EWR.
Opened in 1937, Exeter International is located at Clyst Honiton and serves the city of Exeter in Devon.

The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Key West International, featuring one of the shortest runways in the U.S., opted for EYW.
Named after former Minister of Public Works, Juan Pistarini, the Buenos Aires airport’s code comes from Ezeiza Partido where the airport is located.
Built on the island of Vágar by the British Army during WWII, Vágar Airport is the only airport in the Faroe Islands.
Also known as Algarve Airport, Faro International opened in 1966. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Faro.
Hector International is named after Martin Hector, local businessman who donated the land on which the aiport now sits. It serves the nearby cities of Fargo and Moorhead.
Located about 60 miles south of its namesake national park, Fresno Yosemite International Airport was renamed in 1947 from Fresno Air Terminal.
Before being renamed to honor Montana’s natural beauty, Glacier Park International was known as Flathead County Airport.

Airport_name: Fiumicino – Aeroporto Internazionale Leonardo da Vinci
Airport_description: Rome’s international airport honors the original Renaissance man, Leonardo da Vinci. It is often referred to as just Fiumicino Airport, explaining its airport code of FCO.
Martinique International is named after Aimé Césaire, French author and politician. Located in the suburb of Le Lamentin, it serves the capital city of Fort-de-France.
Established in 1915, Friedrichshafen Airport was the site of the very first Zeppelin passenger flights. Its three-letter code honors the city of Friedrichshafen.
Fes–Saïss Airport, or just Saïss Airport, serves the second-largest city in Morocco, Fes. It gets its airport code from the city’s alternate spelling: Fez.
As its name suggests, First Flight Airport is the location where in 1903 the Wright Brothers first achieved heavier-than-air flight. It is also the location of the Wright Brothers National Memorial.
Fair Isle Airport features a single runway and no hangars and is often used for flight instruction.

Airport_address: Kinshasa Democratic Republic of the Congo
Airport_description: N’Djili International is named after the nearby Ndjili River. The airport was built while the Congo was under Belgian rule, so it is said its airport code comes from the word Flemish.
Originally used as a military airfield, Flughafen Karlsruhe/Baden-Baden is located in the town of Rheinmünster and is a part of Baden Airpark.

Venango Regional is also known as Chess Lamberton Field, named after the grandson of Judge Robert Lamberton, founder of the first bank in Venango County. Its airport code comes from the nearby town of Franklin.
Flagstaff Pulliam Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the Arizona city of Flagstaff.
Formerly Broward County Airport, Fort Lauderdale–Hollywood International serves the greater Miami area, situated between the cities of Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood, Florida.
Florianópolis Airport’s name honors former governor Hercílio Luz, but its airport code honors its home in Florianópolis.
Formally known as Amerigo Vespucci Airport after the Italian cartographer, Florence Airport is located in the suburb of Peretola.

Airport_address: Santa Cruz das Flores Azores Portugal
Airport_description: Inaugurated in 1972, Flores Airport is located on the island of Flores, Portuguese for “Flowers.”
Originally a military airfield built in 1935, Memmingen Airport gets its three-letter code from its German translation: Flughafen Memmingen.
Located in the town of Greven, Flughafen Münster Osnabrück is a minor airport that serves the northern part of North Rhine-Westphalia and the surrounding areas since 1974.
Lungi International is located across the Sierra Leone River from Freetown in the town of Lungi. Its airport code stands for Freetown Airport.
Opened in 1964, Madeira Airport is the only airport in the Portuguese archipelago Madeira in the Atlantic Ocean. It serves the capital city of Funchal.
Bishop International is named after former General Motors board member, Arthur Bishop, whose farmland later became the airport grounds. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Flint.
Fort Dodge Regional gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Fort Dodge, Iowa.
Formerly Cocorote Aiport, Pinto Martins International was renamed in 1952 to honor Euclides Pinto Martins, Brazilian aviation pioneer. Its airport code honors its home in Fortaleza.
Opened commercially in 1936, Germany’s busiest airport is located in the city of Frankfurt.
Opened in 1974, Manas International is named after Manas, the epic hero of the Kyrgyz people. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Bishkek’s former name: Frunze.
Opened in 1975, Figari–Sud Corse Airport is located on the island of Corsica near the commune of Porto-Vecchio. It is also referred to as Figari South Corsica Airport.
Sioux Falls Regional is also known as Joe Foss Field, named after aviator and Medal of Honor recipient Joe Foss.

Airport_address: Saint-Pierre, Saint Pierre and Miquelon France
Airport_description: Opened in 1999, Saint-Pierre Airport serves the city of Saint-Pierre, capital of the overseas collectivity of France, Saint Pierre and Miquelon.
Located in Makinohara and Shimada, Shizuoka Airport is often called Mt. Fuji Shizuoka Airport.
Opened in 1969 and often referred to as El Matorral Airport, Fuerteventura Airport serves the city of Puerto del Rosario and the island of Fuerteventura.
Originally built in 1943 and formerly known as Mushiroda Airfield and Itazuke Air Base, Fukuoka Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of Fukuoka.
Originally built by the U.S. Navy during World War II, Funafuti International now serves the capital city of Funafuti with three flights per week.
Renamed in 1991, Fort Wayne International was previously named Baer Field, after Lieutenant Paul Baer, the first flying ace in U.S. military history. Its airport code honors the city of Fort Wayne.
Used as a military air base until 1976, Gan International gets its airport code from its home on the island of Gan in Addu Atoll.

Lokpriya Gopinath Bordoloi International is named after the freedom fighter and former first Chief Minister of its home state, Assam. Its airport code comes from a former spelling of Guwahati: Gauhati.
Opened in 1984, Sir Seretse Khama International is named after the first President of Botswana. Its three-letter airport code comes from the capital city of Gaborone.
With services started in 1946, Guernsey Airport is located in the parish of Forest. It is the only airport in Guernsey in the Channel Islands.
Owen Roberts International is named after “The Commander” Owen Roberts, aviator and founder of Caribbean International Airways. Its airport code comes from its location on the island of Grand Cayman.
Located 60 miles from Peach Springs on the Hualapai Indian Reservation, Grand Canyon West Airport serves visitors to the canyon and the famous Grand Canyon Skywalk.
Guadalajara International’s ceremonial name honors Miguel Hidalgo, leader of the Mexican War of Independence. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Guadalajara.

Airport_name: Port Lotniczy Gdańsk im. Lecha Wałęsy
Airport_description: Opened in 1974, Gdańsk Lech Walesa Airport is named after Lech Walesa, former Polish president. Its airport code honors its home city of Gdansk.
Before being renamed in 1960, Spokane International was known as Geiger Field, honoring U.S. Army aviator, Major Harold Geiger.

Opened in 1941 by the U.S. Army as Atkinson Field, Cheddi Jagan International was renamed in 1997 in honor of the former President. Located in the town of Timehri, it serves the capital city of Georgetown.
Host to the annual Great Texas Balloon Race, East Texas Regional gets its code from its location and previous name: Gregg County Airport.
Exuma International is located on the island of Great Exuma near the city of Moss Town. Its airport code comes from the Exuma capital city of George Town.
Gibraltar International is one of the “Most Extreme Airports” due to Winston Churchill Avenue directly intersecting the runway. Its airport code comes from its location in Gibraltar.

Airport_name: Aeroporto Internacional do Galeão–Antonio Carlos Jobim
Airport_description: Formerly known as Galeão Air Force Base, Galeão International was created in 1941 on Governador Island’s Galeão Beach in Rio de Janeiro.
Named after the former King of Saudi Arabia, King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz is located in the city of Jizan, alternately spelled Gizan.
Grand Junction Regional is also called Walker Field, named after Walter Walker, a local publisher who helped raise funding and support for the airport’s development.
Known as HMS Sanderling during World War II and later as Glasgow Abbotsinch Airport, Scotland’s second busiest airport honors its home in Glasgow.
Previously named Staverton Airport, Gloucestershire Airport originally opened in 1931 and serves the city of Gloucester.
Inaugurated in 2012, Gelephu Airport has been closed until a new terminal and control tower can be built. Its airport code comes from its home near the town of Gelephu in Sarpang District.
Gimpo International Airport, located in Gangseo-gu of Seoul, was the main airport for Seoul and South Korea until being replaced by Incheon International Airport in 2011.
Originally built in 1928 it was known as Greenville Municipal Airport, and was the origination of Lynyrd Skynyrd’s fatal flight in 1977.
La Gomera airport is located near the town of Playa Santiago on the island of La Gomera. The ‘Z‘ in its code could come from the province of Santa Cruz de Tenerife, but is likely a filler letter.
Formerly Point Salines Airport, Maurice Bishop International was renamed in 2009 in honor of Maurice Bishop, former Prime Minister of Grenada.
Gainesville Regional, renamed in 1977, was previously known as John R. Alison Airport. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Gainesville, Florida.
Also called Cristoforo Colombo Airport, Genoa Airport gets its three-letter code from its home city of Genoa.
Goa Airport is located in the city of Dabolim and is the only airport in the state. Its airport code comes from its name, Goa International.
Colloquially called Nizhny Airport, Strigino International gets its code from Nizhny Novgorod’s former name of Gorky. The ‘J’ isn’t as clear and is likely a filler letter.
China’s Goldmud Airport gets its three-letter code from the city it serves: Golmud of Qinghai province.
Originally opened in 1977, Göteborg Landvetter Airport is Sweden’s second-largest airport and gets its airport code from the city it serves: Gothenburg.
Built during World War II as RAAF Base Gove, Gove Airport serves the city of Nhulunbuy and several Aboriginal communities. It gets its name and airport code from its home on the Gove Peninsula.
Also known as Galapagos Ecological Airport, this airport gets its name from its home in the GalaPagoS Islands on the island of Baltra.
Built in 1942 and named Gulfport Army Airfield, Gulfport–Biloxi International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Gulfport.
Austin Straubel International is named after U.S. Army Air Corps Lt. Col. Austin Straubel, the first Brown County aviator to die while in service. Its code comes from the city of Green Bay.
Killeen–Fort Hood Regional shares its location and airport code with Robert Gray Army Airfield and serves the city of Killeen.
Built in 1965 and located near the village of Vilobí d'Onyar, Girona–Costa Brava Airport gets its code from the city of Girona.
In December of 1999, Kent County International Airport was renamed to honor former President Gerald R. Ford. Its airport code honors its home in Grand Rapids.

Airport_name: Aeroporto Internacional Guarulhos–Governador André Franco Montoro
Airport_description: The São Paulo Airport’s name honors former governor André Franco Montoro, but its airport code honors its home in Guarulhos.
Inaugurated in 1980, Graciosa Airport is located near Santa Cruz on the island of Graciosa. Its code is completed by the letter ‘W’, often used as a filler letter.
Named after Spanish poet Federico García Lorca, Granada Airport is located near Chauchina and serves Granada. Its code is completed by the letter ‘X’, often used as a filler letter.
Originally constructed in 1913, Graz Airport gets its three-letter code from its home city of Graz, Austria.
Often called PTI, Piedmont Triad International dates back to the late 1920s and serves the Piedmont Triad area of North Carolina including the cities of Greensboro, High Point, and Winston-Salem.
Located in Greer and often called Roger Milliken Field, Greenville–Spartanburg International’s code comes from Greenville and Spartanburg, the two cities it serves.
There are no roads to the small city of GuSTavus, so the only way in is by plane or boat.
Golden Triangle Regional Airport serves the Golden Triangle region of Mississippi, made by the three cities of Columbus, Starkville, and West Point.

La Aurora International was developed as Guatemala City Air Base by the U.S. Army Air Forces during World War II. In 1949, the base was closed and handed over to Guatemala. Today it is the primary airport in Guatemala.
Gunnison–Crested Butte Regional Airport is a county-owned public airport that serves the Gunnison County valley and nearby Crested Butte ski resort in Colorado.

Airport_name: Antonio B. Won Pat International Airport
Airport_description: Originally built in 1943 by the Japanese Navy, Antonio B. Won Pat International gets its airport code from its home on the island of Guam.
Originally built by the U.S. Army during World War II, Gurney Airport was named after RAAF Squadron Leader C.R. Gurney and now serves the city of Alotau.
Atyrau Airport is the lowest commercial aiport in the world at 22m below sea level. Its three-letter code comes from the city’s former name of Guryev, with a ‘W’ replacing the letter ‘V’.
Started in 1919, Geneva International is partially located in both the municipalities of Meyrin and Le Grand-Saconnex. Its airport code comes from the city it serves, Geneva.
In 2004, Baku’s airport was renamed and changed its airport code from BAK to GYD in honor of former Azerbaijan President Heydar Aliyev, sometimes spelled Gaydar Aliev.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional José Joaquín de Olmedo
Airport_description: José Joaquín de Olmedo International is named after former President José Joaquín de Olmedo. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Guayaquil, Ecuador.

Inaugurated in 1955, Santa Genoveva International is named after Genoveva Torres Morales and its code comes from Goiânia. The ‘Y’ could come from Goyaz, Goiás state’s former name, but it is likely a filler letter.
Opened in 1998, Yasser Arafat International was closed and abandoned in 2000 after its radar station and control tower were bombed. Its airport code comes from its home in the Gaza Strip.
Prince Said Ibrahim International is named after the former President of Comoros and serves the capital city of Moroni. Its airport code comes from the village of Hahaya where it’s located.
Located in the town of Langenhagen, Hannover Airport’s code combines its home in Hannover and German aviator Karl Jatho, who also lends his name to one of the terminals.
Haikou Meilan International is the airport serving Haikou, the capital of Hainan Province, China.
Hamburg Airport was opened in January of 1911 and serves Germany’s second-largest city, Hamburg.
Opened in 1978, Noi Bai International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Hanoi.
Upgraded to an international airport in 2012, Hanimaadhoo Airport is located in Haa Dhaalu Atoll. Its airport code comes from the island of Hanimaadhoo, plus a helpful ‘Q’ as a filler letter.
Originally Rancho-Boyeros Airport, José Martí International is named after Cuban national hero and poet, José Martí. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Havana.
Hat Yai International is an airport in southern Thailand near the city of Hat Yai. Its code comes from an alternate spelling, Haad Yai.
Located in the city of Vantaa, Finland’s busiest airport was originally built for the 1952 Summer Olympics in Helsinki.
Often referred to as Nikos Kazantzakis Airport, Heraklion International is Greece’s second largest airport and serves the island of Crete.
Opened in 1974, Hammerfest Airport is Norway’s third-busiest regional airport and serves Hammerfest.
Hargeisa Egal International is named after Muhammad Haji Ibrahim Egal, former Prime Minister of Somalia. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Hargeisa.
Originally opened in 2000 and replacing Hangzhou Jianqiao Airport, Hangzhou Xiaoshan International gets its airport code from its home in Hangzhou.
The Heligoland Airport is situated on the small island Düne near the main island Heligoland. It serves mainly small tourist flights towards Bremerhaven and Büsum.
Originally Hahn Air Base, Frankfurt–Hahn Airport gets its name and airport code from the nearby village of Hahn in Rhineland-Palatinate.
Formerly known as Henderson Field after U.S. Marine Corps Major Lofton R. Henderson, Honiara International gets its airport code from the city of Honiara.
Opened in 1961, Hakodate Airport gets its airport code from its home in the city of Hakodate.
Hong Kong International is located on the island of Chek Lap Kok and is often called Chek Lap Kok Airport. Its three-letter airport code stands for Hong Kong.
Phuket International is an important gateway to Thailand for tourists visiting Phuket Island. It is Thailand’s third busiest airport.

Halim Perdanakusuma International is Jakarta’s primary airport for military, private, and government flights. It is named after Air Vice-Marshal and national hero Abdul Halim Perdanakusuma for his service in World War II.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional General Ignacio Pesqueira García
Airport_description: Often called just Hermosillo Airport, General Ignacio Pesqueira García International is named after Ignacio Pesqueira, 19th century Mexican army general. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Hermosillo.
Up until 1952, the Tokyo Airport was officially named after Haneda, the former fishing town where it is now located. Many still call it the Haneda Airport.
Honolulu International was recently renamed to honor Daniel K. Inouye, U.S. Senator and Medal of Honor recipient. Its airport code honors its home in Honolulu.
Hana Airport is a single runway located near the town of Hana, on the east shore of Maui.
Al-Ahsa International is a single runway airport that serves the city of Al-Ahsa, also known as Hofuf.

Originally a postal airport which opened in 1943, Frank País Airport is now home to the Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces Eastern Command. The airport gets its code from Holguín, the city in which it’s located.
Inaugurated in 1971 and rennovated in 2001, Horta International is located in Castelo Branco on Faial Island and serves the city of Horta.
Memorial Field Airport gets its three-letter airport code from the city of Hot Springs and serves the nearby Hot Springs National Park.
Once named after aviator Howard Hughes, Houston’s oldest commercial airport was renamed in 1967 to honor former Texas governor William P. Hobby.
Ørsta–Volda Airport is located between the cities of Ørsta and Volda, but gets its three-letter code from the nearby villge of Hovden.

Airport_name: Sân bay Quốc tế Cát Bi
Airport_description: Undergoing rennovations in 2015, Cat Bi International gets its airport code from its home in Hai Phong.
Built during World War II for the Air National Guard, Westchester County Airport gets its airport code from three Westchester towns: Harrison, Purchase, and North Castle.
Originally built during World War II, Bowerman Airport is named after Lt. Robert C. Bowerman, U.S. Air Force pilot. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Hoquiam.
Opened in 1957 as Salisbury Airport, Harare International serves the city of Harare in Zimbabwe.
Hurghada International is the second busiest airport in Egypt and gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Hurghada.
Mattala Rajapaksa International is named after the Rajapaksas, a prominent political family. Its airport codes comes from its location near Hambantota, Sri Lanka.
Formerly Harlingen Air Force Base, Valley International is now the second busiest airport in the Rio Grande Valley. Its three-letter code honors its home in Harlingen.
Opened in 1967, Huntsville International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Huntsville.
Before it was renamed, Terre Haute International was known as Hulman Field, named after Anton “Tony” Hulman, Jr. who donated the land for the airport’s construction.
Huahine – Fare Airport is located in the commune of Fare and serves the city of Huahine in French Polynesia.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Alférez FAP David Figueroa Fernandini
Airport_description: Serving primarily private and charter flights, David Figueroa Fernandini Airport get its three-letter code from the city of Huánuco.

Humberside Airport is an international airport situated in the east of England. Previously Kirmington Airport, it was renamed in 1964 to Humberside. With the code HUM already taken, it borrows a ‘Y’ from its region of Yorkshire.

Founded in 1928, Barnstable Municipal is also called Boardman/Polando Field, named after aviators Russell Boardman and John Polando. It serves Cape Cod and is located in the village of Hyannis in Barnstable.
Rajiv Gandhi International was named to honor the former Indian prime minister. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Hyderabad.
Dulles International Airport’s three-letter code was once DIA. When hand-written, it was often misread as DCA, another Washington airport. It was reversed to IAD to avoid confusion.
In 1997 the airport was renamed after former President George H.W. Bush, but was previously known as Intercontinental Airport Houston.
First established as a military airfield during the Spanish Civil War, Ibiza Airport is located in Ibiza and serves the Balearic Islands.
The airport that serves the Seoul Metro Area is actually located on a man-made piece of land between Yeongjong and Yongyu islands, west of Incheon’s city center.
The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Formerly named Mid-Continent Airport, Wichita opted for ICT.
Owned by the city of Idaho Falls and formerly known as Fanning Field, Idaho Falls Regional’s current terminal was built in 1959 and has been remodeled several times since.
Devi Ahilyabai Holkar is named after Maharani Ahilya Bai Holkar, Holkar Queen of the Maratha Empire. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Indore.
Started in 1923 as a military airfield, Kyiv International’s terminal building wasn’t built until 1949. Located in the neighborhood of Zhuliany, its airport code comes from the capital city of Kiev.
Laughlin/Bullhead International is located in Bullhead City, Arizona, but also serves Laughlin, Nevada. The airport claims its three-letter code stands for International Fun Place.

Airport_name: Aeroporto Internacional de Foz do Iguaçu/Cataratas
Airport_description: Foz do Iguaçu International is named after Iguazu Falls (Cataratas do Iguaçu) and gets its airport code from the city of Foz do Iguaçu.
In April 2021, NASA’s Ingenuity Mars Helicopter took the first powered, controlled flight on another planet. The location was named after the Wright Brothers, with a code for Ingenuity.
Located in Ahmadabad and serving the city of Tehran, Imam Khomeini Airport is named after Ruhollah Khomeini, leader of the 1979 Iranian Revolution.
Opened in 2010, Lleida-Alguaire Airport is located in Alguaire and serves Lleida. With airport code LLE already taken, it uses ILD which comes from the city’s historic name of Ilerda.
Before being renamed in 1976, Indianapolis International was called Weir-Cook Municipal, honoring World War I flying ace Colonel Harvey Weir-Cook. Its airport code honors its home in Indianapolis.
Opened in 1925, Innsbruck airport (often called Kranebitten Airport) serves Western Austria and the city of Innsbruck. It is very popular in winter for skiers visiting St. Anton in the Tyrol region.
Built during World War II under Japanese occupation, Nauru International is the only airport on the Island of Nauru.
Originally built in 1940 as a Royal Air Force station, Inverness Airport is located in Dalcross, Highland and serves the city of Inverness.
Started as an airfield in 1928, Isle of Man Airport is located in Ronaldsway and is often referred to as Ronaldsway Airport.

The most remote airport in the world, Mataveri International serves as the main entry point for people visiting or living on Easter Island. Its airport code comes from the Spanish name for Easter Island, Isla de Pascua.
Sultan Azlan Shah Airport serves Ipoh, a city in the state of Perak, Malaysia.
Usiminas Airport is owned by and named after Usiminas, a Brazilian steel manufacturer. Located in Santana do Paraíso, its airport code comes from the city it serves, Ipatinga.
Sharing a runway with Los Cóndores Air Base, Diego Aracena International gets its airport code from its home city of Iquique.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Coronel FAP Francisco Secada Vignetta
Airport_description: Coronel FAP Francisco Secada Vignetta International is one of the main gateways to the Peruvian Amazon Rainforest. Its airport code comes from the city of Iquitos.
Renamed in 2008, Benazir Bhutto International honors the former prime minister of Pakistan. Its airport code honors its home in the twin cities of Rawalpindi and Islamabad.
Previously High Cross Farm and officially opened in 1939, St Mary’s Airport is located in St Mary’s in the Isles of Scilly near Cornwall.
In 2019, Istanbul Atatürk Airport’s code was changed from IST to ISL and no longer serves commercial passenger flights.
Long Island Airport got its start in the 1940s and is named after U.S. Army General Douglas MacArthur. Its airport code comes from its original name of Islip Airport.
In 2019, all commercial flights were transfered from Istanbul Atatürk Airport to the newly running Istanbul Airport.
Formerly Itami Airport, Osaka International was renamed following its return to Japanese control in 1959. While it serves Osaka, it is actually located in the city of Itami.

One theory about ITO says it was named after an early station manager, Mr. Ito. Though with HIL and ILO already taken, Hilo International likely took its three-letter code from the nickname Hilo Town.
Ivanovo Yuzhny Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Ivanovo. Unable to use the ‘V’, it swapped in a helpful filler ‘W’.
Agartala Airport is named after the capital of Tripura state in India. Its airport code comes from the new code series for India issued by IATA, IX, plus the city of Agartala.

Located in the town of Siliguri, Bagdogra Airport serves the Darjeeling district of West Bengal. Its airport code comes from the new code series for India issued by IATA, IX, plus the city of Bagdogra.

Chandigarh International is named after the union territory in northern India, also known as “The City Beautiful.” Its airport code comes from the new code series for India issued by IATA, IX, plus the city of Chandigarh.
Madurai Airport was established in 1957, after serving as a military airfield. Its airport code comes from the new code series for India issued by IATA, IX, plus the city of Madurai.

Veer Savarkar International is named after the Indian freedom activist Vinayak Damodar Savarkar. Its airport code comes from the new code series for India issued by IATA, IX, with the letter Z as filler.
Wyoming’s busiest airport, the only commercial airport located inside a U.S. national park, gets its airport code from the nearby town of Jackson.
