Jaipur International is the only international airport in the state of Rajasthan. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Jaipur.
Francisco Carlé Airport serves the city of Jauja and its surrounding cities. Its airport code honors its home city.
Jacksonville International’s three-letter code is JAX, a commonly used abbreviation for the city of Jacksonville, used by residents, local businesses, and services.

King Abdulaziz International is named after the first monarch of Saudi Arabia, and because of its proximity to Makkah, is best known for its spacious Hajj terminal. Its airport code honors the city of Jeddah.
Opened by The States of Jersey in 1937, Jersey Airport serves the Bailiwick of Jersey in the Channel Islands. It serves about 1.4 million passengers annually.
In 1963, Idlewild Airport was renamed in dedication to John F. Kennedy. Unlike many other airports, it also changed its three-letter airport code from IDL to JFK.
Kapalua Airport serves the Kapalua Resort area and the nearby town of Lahaina. Its airport code comes from John Henry Magoon, the president of Hawaiian Airlines when the airport was being developed.
Opened in 1948, Djibouti–Ambouli International is located in the town of Ambouli and serves Djibouti City.
Quanzhou Jinjiang International is a dual-use military and public airport located in Jinjiang that serves the larger city of Quanzhou in Fujian, China.
Previously Johannesburg International, O. R. Tambo International was renamed in 2006 to honor Oliver Tambo, former African National Congress President.
Adisucipto International serves the Yogyakarta (previously anglicized Jogjakarta) metro area, and honors Agustinus Adisucipto, national hero and early figure in the Indonesian Air Force.

Airport_name: Aeroporto de Joinville-Lauro Carneiro de Loyola
Airport_description: Lauro Carneiro de Loyola Airport is named after Lauro Falcão Carneiro, local entrepreneur and politician. Its three-letter code comes from the city of Joinville.
Presidente Castro Pinto International is named after the former Governor of Paraíba. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of João Pessoa.

Opened in 1971, Kilimanjaro International is often called the “Gateway to Africa’s Wildlife Heritage” and serves those visiting Mount Kilimanjaro National Park. Originally it was named just Kilimanjaro Airport.

Skiathos Airport is popular for its close take-offs and landings due to its short runway, similar to SXM. The ‘SI’ in its code comes from Skiathos, while the ‘J’ is likely a filler letter. JSI is one of nine Greek airports whose code begins with J.
Juba International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the capital of South Sudan, Juba.
Named after Manco Cápac, the “royal founder” of the Inca civilization in Cusco, Inca Manco Cápac International gets its three-letter code from its home in Juliaca.
The oldest airport in Nigeria, Mallam Aminu International is named after 20th century political leader, Aminu Kano. Its three-letter code honors its home in the city of Kano.
Built in the 1960s and renamed in 2014, Hamid Karzai International is named after the former Afghan President. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Kabul.
Originally opened in 1959 and then reorganized in 1993, Boryspil International serves the capital of Ukraine, Kiev, from the city of Boryspil.
Sultan Ismail Petra Airport is named after the thirteenth Sultan of Kelantan. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of Kota Bharu.
Krabi International serves the province of Krabi in Thailand. The ‘V’ in its airport code is a filler letter.
Kuching International is located just south of Kuching city center and serves the entire southwestern region of Sarawak, Malaysia.
Also known as Reykjavík-Keflavík Airport, Iceland’s largest airport is located near the town of Keflavík and 50 km south of the capital city of Reykjavík.
Kerman International gets its airport code from its home in the city and province of Kerman.
Located in the suburb of Kanombe, Kigali International gets its airport code from the capital city of Kigali.
Built in 1938 as a Japanese Navy air base, Kaohsiung International serves the city of Kaohsiung. Its code is completed by a second letter ‘H’, used as a filler letter.
Jinnah International is named after Muhammad Ali Jinnah, founder of Pakistan. Its airport code comes from its former name and home in the city of Karachi.
A popular tourist gateway, Kish International gets its three-letter code from its home on Kish Island.
The nation’s gateway, Norman Manley International is situated less than twenty minutes from Kingston, Jamaica’s capital city and the commercial center of the Caribbean.
Flights to Chișinău began as early as 1926. Chișinău International get its airport code from the historic English spelling of Chișinău, Kishinev.

Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Fully built on an artificial island, Kansai Airport gets its code from the Kansai region, plus that helpful ‘X’.
Kalibo International serves the general area of Kalibo and is one of two airports serving the small island of Boracay.
Airport Klagenfurt is Austria’s southernmost international airport. Initially a military airport, it now serves as a year-round tourist gate to Carinthia in southern Austria.
With construction completing in 2011, Kunming Changshui International was originally to be called Zheng He Airport. It serves the city of Kunming.
Kualanamu International is the busiest airport in Sumatra, built to replace the Polonia Airport and opened in 2013. It serves the Kuala Namu region (sometimes spelled Kuala Nemu, or Kuala Namo).
Opened in 1970 and originally known as Ke-āhole Airport, Kona International serves Kailua-Kona, usually referred to as just Kona.
Located in the city of Kokshetau in Kazakhstan, Kokshetau Airport gets its three-letter code from its former name, Kokchetav Trofimovka Airport.

Airport_name: Kraków Airport im. Jana Pawła II
Airport_description: Opened in 1964, Kraków–Balice Airport was renamed in 1995 to honor Pope John Paul II who before the Papacy had served as Archbishop for the city of Kraków.
Kiruna Airport is the homebase for the Spaceport Sweden project, a venture in space and air travel. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Kiruna.
Krasnodar International, also known as Pashkovsky Airport, serves the southern Krasnodar region of Russia.
Originally opened in 1939, Kristiansand Airport is located in Kjevik and gets its three-letter code from the city of Kristiansand.
Khartoum International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the capital of Sudan, Khartoum.
Kosrae International is located on an artificial island in eastern Micronesia. It serves the state of Kosrae.
Shahid Ashrafi Esfahani Airport is named after Ashrafi Esfahani, Iranian religious leader. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of Kermanshah.
Kostanay International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Kostanay.
Opened as an airfield in 1949, Tribhuvan International is named after Tribhuwan Bir Bikram Shah, former King of Nepal. Its airport code comes from its home city of Kathmandu.
Kittilä Airport is a general aviation and commercial airport located in the city of Kittilä, inside the Arctic Circle, and serves Northern Finland.
An international airport, Katowice Airport is the fourth busiest in Poland. Actually located in the village of Pyrzowice, its three-letter code comes from the city it serves: Katowice.
Sultan Ahmad Shah Airport serves Kuantan, a city in the state of Pahang, Malaysia.
Kushiro Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Kushiro.
Upon completion, Kuala Lumpur International replaced Subang Airport as Kuala Lumpur’s primary passenger airport. At the same time, it took the KUL code and Subang received a new code of SZB.
Kaunas International is the second-busiest civil airport in Lithuania and the fourth-busiest in the Baltic states.
Opened in 1940, Kuopio Airport is actually located in the city of Siilinjärvi, but serves the city of Kuopio.
Opened in 1997, Guiyang Longdongbao International gets airport code from the city’s former English name: Kweiyang.
Located in Farwaniyah, Kuwait International is headquarters for the Kuwait Air Force at Al Mubarak Air Base. Its airport code honors its home in Kuwait.
Completed in 1979, Kazan International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Kazan.
Kyzylorda Airport gets its three-letter code from the city’s former name of Kzyl-Orda.
Quatro de Fevereiro International translates to February 4, an important national holiday in Angola. Its airport code honors the capital city of Luanda.
Purdue University Airport was the first university-owned airport in the U.S. and is the second busiest in Indiana. It is located in West Lafayette and serves its sister city of Lafayette.
Capital Region International started passenger service in 1929. Located in DeWitt Township, it serves the capital city of Lansing.
Formerly called Alamo Field, McCarron Airport was renamed in 1948 after Pat McCarran, a senator and author of the Civil Aeronautics Act. Its airport code honors its home in Las Vegas.
Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. LA (Los Angeles) became LAX.
Opened in 1931 as Yeadon Aerodrome, Leeds Bradford Airport serves the cities of Leeds and Bradford, along with the Yorkshire region.
Opened in 1937 and originally named South Plains Airport, Lubbock International is now named after Preston E. Smith, former Texas governor. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Lubbock.
Sometimes called “Hamburg Lübeck”, Lübeck Airport was originally built as an airbase during World War I.
Built in 1921, North Platte was the first lighted airfield in the Unitd States. In 1941 it was renamed Lee Bird Field to honor a local pilot who was killed in training during World War I.
Komodo Airport is located on the island of Flores and serves visitors to Komodo National Park, home of the Komodo dragon. Its three-letter code comes from the nearby town of Labuan Bajo.
Labuan Airport serves the country of Malaysia and gets its airport code from the territory of Labuan.
Libreville International is officially named after Leon M’ba, the first Prime Minister and President of Gabon. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Libreville.
Larnaca Airport was developed in 1974 after Turkey invaded Cyprus and Nicosia International subsequently closed. It now serves the city of Larnaca.
Formerly known as Alvedro Airport, A Coruña Airport was inaugurated in 1963. Its airport code comes from the Spanish city of La Coruña, Galicia.
Opened in 1942, Rickenbacker International is now named after World War I pilot Eddie Rickenbacker. It was originally known as Lockbourne Army Airfield for the nearby town of Lockbourne.
Located in the Royal Docks and near London’s financial district, London City Airport primarily serves business travelers. Recently though, it has started serving more leisure destinations.
Originally built during World War II, City of Derry Airport was renamed in 1994. Its previous name was Londonderry Eglinton Airport.

Pulkovo Airport opened in the city of Leningrad in 1932. In 1991, the city returned to its original name of Saint Petersburg and kept the airport code, now associated with LED lights for many visitors.
Almería Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Almería.
Opened in 1986, Leipzig/Halle Airport gets its airport code from the city of Leipzig. The ‘J’ is a phonetic replacement for the ‘G’ in Leipzig.
Used as an aviation school during the 1940s, León Airport opened commercially in 1964 serving the city of León.
Andorra is one of five countries without an airport. Opened in 1982, La Seu d'Urgell Airport in Spain serves passengers traveling to Andorra and the nearby areas.
Located in the Horse Capital of the World, Blue Grass Airport opened in 1946. Its airport code honors its home in Lexington, Kentucky.
Opened in 1930, Lafayette Regional gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Lafayette.
Lomé–Tokoin Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Lomé and the former federation of French West Africa.
LaGuardia has had many names and the land it sits on was once an amusement park. Its current name comes from Fiorello La Guardia, former mayor of New York who championed its construction.
Formerly named Daugherty Field after barnstormer Earl S. Daugherty, Long Beach Airport was once the site for one of the world’s first flying schools.
Often called Liège-Bierset, Liège Airport is located in Grâce-Hollogne and serves the city of Liège, Belgium.
Located in the town of Padang Matsirat, Langkawi International serves the Langkawi islands in Malaysia. It hosts an international maritime and aerospace exhibition every two years.
Close to London, Gatwick Airport is the second-largest airport in Britain. It’s the world’s busiest single-use runway and is named after Gatwick manor house that used to stand on the site.
Renamed in 2003, Allama Iqbal International honors Muhammad Iqbal, poet-philosopher and advocate for the Pakistan Movement. Its airport code honors its former name and home in Lahore.
London Heathrow takes its name from Heathrow, a hamlet north-west of where the (then) small airfield was started in 1929.
Opened in 1949, Lihue Airport is the primary airport on the Hawaiian island of Kauai. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Lihue.
Also known as Lesquin Airport, Lille Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of Lille.
Originally named Lima-Callao Airport, Jorge Chávez International was renamed in 1965 to honor the Peruvian aviator.
Milan Linate Airport is officially named Airport Enrico Forlanini after the Italian inventor. Its airport code comes from the village of Linate in the town of Peschiera Borromeo.
Daniel Oduber Quirós International is named after the former President of Costa Rica and serves the city of Liberia.
Portugal’s busiest airport is named for its neighboring parish, Portela, but its airport code comes from the capital city of Lisbon.

Airport_name: Bill and Hillary Clinton National Airport
Airport_description: Still referred to as Adams Field, Arkansas’ largest airport is now named after former U.S. President Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary. Its aiport code honors its home in Little Rock.
In 2007, Ljubljana Jože Pučnik Airport was renamed to honor Jože Pučnik, considered one of the fathers of Slovenian independence. Its airport code honors its home in Ljubljana.
Chaudhary Charan Singh International is named after India’s sixth Prime Minister. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Lucknow.
Sometimes referred to as Kamuzu Airport, Lilongwe International gets its three-letter code from the capital city of Malawi, Lilongwe.
Opened in 2004, Limbang Airport replaced the Limbang airfield built in the 1960s. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of Limbang.

The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Crater Lake - Klamath Regional, with origins dating back to 1928, chose other letters from Klamath Falls.
Used during World War II as Lincoln Army Air Field, Lincoln Airport’s code gets its first two letters from the city of Lincoln. The ‘K’ works phonetically and as a filler letter.

Linz Airport serves as gateway to the third largest city in Austria, which northern and southern parts are divided by the Danube river, similar to Austria’s capital – Vienna. Its airport code is just one letter short of the city’s full name – Linz

Built to replace the Selaparang Airport and opened in 2011, Lombok International Airport serves the city of Mataram, the capital of the province of West Nusa Tenggara.  It receives its code from the district on the island where it is located, LOmbok Praya
Formerly Lagos International, Murtala Muhammed International was renamed to honor assassinated head of state, General Murtala Ramat Muhammed. Its airport code honors its home in Lagos.
Located on the island of Gran Canaria on the Bay of Gando, Gran Canaria Airport is sometimes (incorrectly) called Las Palmas Airport.
The highest international airport in the world, at 13,325 ft (4061 m), El Alto’s airport code honors the nearby city of La Paz, Bolivia.
Opened in 1930 and known locally as Speke Airport, Liverpool John Lennon Airport is named after late musician John Lennon of the Beatles. Its airport code honors its home in Liverpool.
Luang Prabang International is one of few international airports in the country of Laos. Its three-letter code comes from Luang Prabang, plus a helpful ‘Q’ as a filler letter.
Previously known as Laredo Army Airfield during World War II, Laredo International now serves the city of Laredo, Texas.

Airport_name: Aéroport de La Rochelle – Ile de Ré
Airport_description: La Rochelle Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in La Rochelle. It also serves the nearby Île de Ré.
Located near U.S. Army Fort McCoy military base, La Crosse Regional serves passengers traveling to west-central Wisconsin, southeastern Minnesota, and northeastern Iowa.
Previously Luton International, London Luton Airport was renamed in 1990 to emphasize its proximity to London. The airport itself is located in the town of Luton.
Cincinnati Municipal is also known as Lunken Field, named after Eshelby Lunken and the Lunken family who donated the land where the airport now sits.
Renamed in 2011 in honor of Zambia’s first president, Kenneth Kaunda International is located in Lusaka, formerly the capital of Northern Rhodesia.
Located in the town of Findel, Luxembourg’s only international airport gets its airport code from its home country of Luxembourg.
Harry Mwanga Nkumbula International is named after the nationalist leader who fought for Northern Rhodesian independence. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Livingstone.
Greenbrier Valley Airport is located in Greenbrier County and gets its three-letter airport code from the nearby city of Lewisburg.
Lviv Danylo Halytskyi International is named after 13th century King Daniel of Galicia. Its airport code comes from the Polish spelling of Lviv: Lwów.
Luxor International serves the many tourists who visit the Nile River and the Valley of the Kings. Its three-letter code comes from its home in Luxor, Egypt.
Svalbard Airport gets its name from the city it serves. Its airport code comes from the nearby town of Longyearbyen.
In 2000, Lyon’s airport was renamed to honor French aviator Antoine de Saint-Exupéry. Its airport code comes from its original name, Lyon Satolas Airport.
Chennai International is located in Tirusulam, a suburb of Chennai, but gets its three-letter code from the city’s former name, Madras, changed in 1996.
Spain’s largest airport honors former Prime Minister Adolfo Suárez, but its airport code honors its home in the capital city of Madrid.

Airport_name: Midland International Air and Space Port
Airport_description: Midland International is located between the cities of Midland and Odessa. Its airport code comes from its time as a training base during World War II, named Midland Army Airfield.
Opened in 1969, Menorca Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in Mahón on the island of Menorca.
Built during World War II, Marshall Islands International is sometimes referred to as Amata Kabua Airport. Its airport code comes from the city and atoll named Majuro.
Once called Ringway Airport because of its location in the parish of Ringway, the UK’s third busiest airport serves the city of Manchester.
Brigadeiro Eduardo Gomes International is named after Brazilian Air Marshall Eduardo Gomes. Its airport code comes from an alternate spelling of Manaus, Manáos.
Named after Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi, Moi International serves the city of Mombasa.
Sangster International is named in honor of former Jamaican Prime Minister Sir Donald Sangster. Its airport code honors its home in Montego Bay, Jamaica.
Formerly known as Freeland Tri-City Airport, MBS International is the third busiest airport in Michigan. Its airport code honors the three communities it serves: Midland, Bay City, and Saginaw.
Before changing its name in 1972, Kansas City International was originally known as Mid-Continent International Airport.
Renamed in 1976, Orlando’s airport was originally a military airfield known as McCoy Airforce Base, honoring Colonel Michael Norman Wright McCoy.
Opened in 1973 and originally named Seeb International, the largest airport in Oman is located in the city of Muscat.
Founded in 1927, Mason City Municipal gets its three-letter code from the two organizations that founded it, Mason City Chamber of Commerce and the Clausen-Worden Post of the American Legion.
Renamed in 1999, Maceió/Zumbi dos Palmares International is named after Zumbi dos Palmares, 17th century hero and freedom fighter.
Often called Manado Airport, Sam Ratulangi International is named after the Minahasan independence hero Sam Ratulangi. Its airport code comes from nearby Manado City.

Opened in 1985, José María Córdova International is named after a General of the Colombian army. Actually located in the city of Rionegro, it gets its three-letter code from the city it serves, Medellín.
Mandalay International is one of three airports in Myanmar. Its three-letter code honors its home in Mandalay.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Mar del Plata “Ástor Piazzolla”
Airport_description: Named after an Argentine musician, Astor Piazzolla International is located in Mar del Plata. With MDP already taken, its code uses the letter ‘Q’ in place of the ‘P’.
Often called HIA incorrectly, Harrisburg International’s airport code comes from Middletown, a nearby Harrisburg suburb.
Once called Chicago Air Park and later Chicago Municipal, Midway International was renamed in 1949 to honor World War II’s Battle of Midway.
Named after the former Mendoza governor, Francisco Gabrielli International gets its three-letter code from the city of Mendoza.

Airport_name: Prince Mohammad bin Abdulaziz International Airport
Airport_description: Opened in 1950, Prince Mohammad bin Abdulaziz Internationali is named after the former Crown Prince. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Medina.
Located in the suburb of Tullamarine, Melbourne Airport is often called “Tullamarine Airport” or just “Tulla.” Its airport code comes from the city of Melbourne.
In 1969, Memphis Municipal Airport changed its name to “International”, presenting Memphis as a hub for international travel and cargo.
Once called Central Airport and most commonly referred to as Mexico City International, Mexico’s busiest airport is named in honor of 19th century president, Benito Juárez.
Mansfield Lahm Regional is home to Mansfield Lahm Air National Guard Base and hosts Mansfield Airport Day each year. Its airport code honors the city of Mansfield.
Nicaragua’s busiest airport is named after Augusto César Sandino, national hero and revolutionary. Its three-letter airport code comes from the capital city of Managua.
Founded in 1955 as a small airstrip, Düsseldorf Mönchengladbach Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Mönchengladbach.
Previously known as Dannelly Field, Montgomery Regional is located in and serves the city of Montgomery.
Shahid Hashemi Nejad Airport is the second busiest airport in Iran and gets its three-letter code from its home in Mashhad.
Manchester Airport added “-Boston Regional” to its name in 2005 to serve as another option for Boston travelers. Its airport code still honors its home in Manchester.
Once known as the 36th Street Airport, the three-letter code MIA stands for Miami and not the popular initialism for “missing in action.”
Started as a military air base, Murcia-San Javier airport is located in San Javier and serves the cities of Murcia and Cartagena.

Charles B. Wheeler Downtown Airport in Missouri was originally Kansas City’s main airport, until the FAA called it “the most dangerous major airport in the country” and it was replaced with Kansas City International in 1972.
General Mitchell International honors U.S. Army Air Service General Billy Mitchell, but its airport code honors its home in Milwaukee.
Located in Norton Shores, construction on Muskegon County Airport began in 1931. Its airport codes honors its home in Muskegon County, Michigan.
Located between the villages of Luqa and Gudja near the capital city of Valletta, Malta International is the only airport serving the nation of Malta.
Melbourne International dates back to the late 1920s and gets its airport code from its home in the city of Melbourne, Florida.
Ibrahim Nasir International is named after the first president of the Maldives. It is located on Hulhule Island, near the capital island of Male.

EuroAirport Basel-Mulhouse-Freiburg has two IATA codes (BSL is the other one). It is located in Saint-Louis, France but is one of only a few airports in the world operated jointly by two countries, in this case France and Switzerland.
The QCIA serves the Quad City Metro area spanning the border of Iowa and Illinois. Its airport code comes from the city it resides in, MoLIne.
Opened in 1969, Melilla Airport serves the city of Melilla, a Spanish enclave in Africa, and the nearby city of Nador, Morocco.
Monroe Regional was previously named Selman Army Airfield after U.S. Navy pilot, Lieutenant Augustus J. Selman. Its three-letter code comes from its home in Monroe, Louisiana.

Commonly still called Teesside International, Durham Tees Valley started as RAF Middleton St. George in 1941. Some say its code comes from Middleton Military Establishment, but the airport itself has said the second ‘M’ is a filler letter.
Primarily used for general aviation, Mammoth Yosemite Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Mammoth Lakes.
Built in 1972 and formerly known as Sturup Airport, Malmö Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in Malmö, plus a helpful ‘X’ as a filler letter.
Originally named Manila International, Ninoy Aquino Airport was renamed in 1987 to honor assassinated Senator Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino, Jr. Its airport code honors the city it serves: Manila.
Fully self-funded and home to a U.S. Coast Guard aviation training center, Mobile Regional serves Mobile, Alabama.
Moomba Airport gets its fun three-letter code from its home in the city of Moomba in South Australia.
Sometimes still called Lourenço Marques Airport, Maputo International get its airport code from its location in the capital city of Maputo, Mozambique.

Airport_address: Miquelon Saint Pierre and Miquelon France
Airport_description: Miquelon Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its location in the Miquelon-Langlade commune in Saint Pierre and Miquelon.
Called RAAF Base Mildura during World War II, Mildura Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of Mildura, plus a helpful ‘Q’ as a filler letter.
Marseille Provence Airport is located in the commune of Marignane and was previously known as Marseille–Marignane Airport. Its airport code comes from the city it serves,  Marseille.
Officially opened in 1945, Plaisance Airport was later renamed to honor former Prime Minister Seewoosagur Ramgoolam. It is located in the southernmost part of Mauritius.
Opened in 1936 and previously named Monterey Peninsula Airport, Monterey Regional was renamed in 2011 and serves the city of Monterey, California.
Formerly Truax Field, named after U.S. Army Air Forces Lieutenant Thomas L. Truax, Dane County Regional’s code honors its home in the city of Madison.
Previously known as Johnson-Bell Field, Missoula International opened in 1941 and serves the city of Missoula, Montana.
Formerly known as Speedway Field and Wold–Chamberlain Field, MSP is now named after Minnesota’s twin cities, Minneapolis and Saint Paul.

Minsk National, formerly known as Minsk-2 (yes, there is a Minsk-1), is the primary airport in Belarus. Its code comes from the city of Minsk. The ‘Q’ works phonetically, but is used as a filler letter.
Located in the town of Beek and previously known as Beek Airfield, Maastricht Aachen Airport serves the cities of Maastricht, Netherlands and Aachen, Germany.
Moshoeshoe I International is named after the founder of the Basotho nation, eventually to become Lesotho. Located in Mazenod, it serves the city of Maseru.
In 2001, the airport was named after jazz legend Louis Armstrong, but was previously called Moisant Field, after aviator John Moisant. Its airport code came from the nearby Moisant Stock Yards.
Dedicated in 1988, Montrose Regional is a non-towered, seasonal airport. Its code gets its first two letters from Montrose. Some say the ‘J’ comes from Jet Airport, but it is likely a filler letter.
In 2014, most air traffic to Swaziland was moved from Matsapha Airport to King Mswati III International. It originally served the city of Manzini, but is located in the town of Matsapha.
Located in Apodaca, Monterrey International is named after Mariano Escobedo, a Mexican Army general and former Governor of Nuevo León.
Rarely called by its full name, Munich Airport is named after German politician Franz Josef Strauss. Its airport code honors its home near the city of Munich.
With military flights using the area as early as 1919, Multan International gets its three-letter airport code from the city of Multan, plus a helpful filler ‘X’.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Carrasco/General Cesáreo L. Berisso
Airport_description: Carrasco International is named after aviation pioneer General Cesáreo L. Berisso. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Montevideo.
Built in 1942 as a naval training facility, Martha’s Vineyard Airport is located near the community of Vineyard Haven on the island of Martha’s Vineyard.

A former U.S. Army air base during World War II, Laurinburg–Maxton Airport is known today primarily as an airliner graveyard. Its code comes in part from Maxton, but the ‘E’ is more of a mystery and is likely a filler letter.
Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Milan’s airport code comes from Cascina Malpensa, where the airport got its start, plus that helpful ‘X’.
Originally opened in 1940 as Gibbs Field, Montgomery Field Airport is now named after aviation pioneer John J. Montgomery.
Formerly Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, Myrtle Beach Airport gained international status in 1996. Its airport code comes from its home in Myrtle Beach.
Myitkyina Airfield was captured by the Japanese Air Force during World War II. Now a passenger airport, it serves the city of Myitkyina in Myanmar.
Due to a short runway, only turbopropeller aircrafts can land at La Nubia Airport. It gets its three-letter code from its city of Manizales.
Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar International is named after the chief architect of the Indian Constitution. Its airport code comes from its home in city of Nagpur.

Used as a U.S. military base during World War II, Nadi International was once called Naval Air Facility Nandi. “Nandi” was an English phonetic spelling used long after the airport’s name was officially changed.
Originally Capodichino Airport, Naples International is located in the Capodichino district in the city of Naples.
In 2006, Lynden Pindling Airport changed its name from Nassau International in honor of the former Prime Minister, Sir Lynden Oscar Pindling.
Augusto Severo International is named after Brazilian aviator Augusto Severo de Albuquerque Maranhão. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Natal.
Jomo Kenyatta International is named after Jomo Kenyatta, Kenya’s first president and prime minister. Its airport code comes from a combination of letters from the capital city of Nairobi.
France’s third busiest airport is named for the regions it serves: the city of Nice and the Côte d'Azur (the French Riviera).
Opened in 1935, Newcastle International served 4.6 million passengers in 2014 making it one of the busiest in the United Kingdom. Its airport code honors its home in Newcastle.
N’Djamena Airport is the only international airport in Chad, serving both civilian and military traffic. Its three-letter code comes from the capital city of N’Djamena.
N’Délé Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of N’Délé in the Central African Republic.
Ningbo Lishe International is the principal airport serving Ningbo, a major city in the Yangtze River Delta region and the second largest city in Zhejiang Province, China.
Chūbu Centrair International serves the Chūbu (central) region of Japan. Located in the city of Nagoya, it replaced Nagoya Airport in 2005 and inherited its airport code too.
Opened as a military aerodome in 1923, Omura Airport began civilian use in 1955. It was later renamed to Nagasaki Airport after the city it serves.

Nicosia International has been closed since the Turkish invasion of Cyprus in 1974 and later became a United Nations controlled Buffer Zone. It previously served as a military and commercial airport for the city of Nicosia.
Diori Hamani International is named after the first President of the Republic of Niger. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Niamey.
Nouakchott International gets its three-letter airport code from Mauritania’s capital city of Nouakchott.
Nanjing Lukou International serves Nanjing and gets its airport code from the city’s former Romanization, Nanking.
Nanning Wuxu International serves the city of Nanning, the capital of Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in China.
One of the busiest airports in Madagascar, Fascene Airport gets its three-letter code from its home on the island of Nosy Be.
Located in St Mawgan in Pydar, Newquay Cornwall Airport began as a civilian airfield in 1933. Its airport code comes from the town of Newquay in Cornwall.
Weeze Airport’s three-letter code comes from its official name, Flughafen Niederrhein, with Niederrhein translating to the “Lower Rhine” that flows nearby.
Upon privitazation in 2004, New Tokyo International Airport was renamed in recognition of the city in which is located, Narita.
Originally built in 1937, Nelson Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Nelson.
Originally a French military airfield, Nantes Atlantique is located southwest of Bouguenais and serves the city of Nantes.

Newcastle Airport is 15 kilometres; 9.2 miles (8 NM) north of Newcastle, New South Wales in Port Stephens. It is the 13th busiest airport in Australia, handling over 1.25 million passengers in the year ended 30 June 2017.
Inaugurated in 1955, Nuremberg Airport is the second-busiest airport in Bavaria. It is christened after German artist Albrecht Dürer and serves the city of Nuremberg.
Norwich International was opened during World War II as RAF Horsham St Faith and is located in the city of Norwich in Norfolk.
Stockholm Skavsta Airport served as a military airbase until 1980 and now serves the city of Stockholm. Its airport code comes from the town of Nyköping, where it’s located.
Oakland International was the departure site for Amelia Earhart’s final flight in 1937. It now serves the eastern part of the San Francisco Bay Area (the East Bay) and the city of Oakland.
Located near the village of North Connel, Scotland’s Oban Airport gets its three-letter code from the town it serves, Oban.
Originally built in 1961, Odessa International serves Ukraine’s third largest city of Odessa.
Kahului Airport is named after its home city, but its airport code honors Hawaiian-born pilot Bertram J. Hogg.
Ohrid Airport is named after Saint Paul the Apostle and serves the city of Ohrid in Macedonia.
Opened in 1933 as Oroku Aerodrome, Naha Airport gets its airport code from its home in Naha, Okinawa.
It may sound like an amusement park, but Will Rogers World Airport honors legendary cowboy and entertainer, Will Rogers. Its airport code honors its home in Oklahoma City.
Eppley Airfield is Nebraska’s largest airport and honors hotel mogul Eugene C. Eppley. Its aiport code honors its home in Omaha.
When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the U.S. Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. Nome Airport then used the next few letters in its home city of Nome to get OME.
Opened in 1965, Mostar International gets its airport code from its home in the village of Ortiješ in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Omsk Tsentralny Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in Omsk Oblast.
Established in 1929, Ontario Municipal was renamed “International” in 1946. In 2006, the “LA” was added to avoid confusion with the Canadian province that shares the name Ontario.
Gold Coast Airport is located in the suburb of Bilinga on the Gold Coast. Its airport code comes from its former name of Coolangatta Airport, an Aboriginal word meaning “Place of Good View.”
Portugal’s second busiest airport is named after former Prime Minister Francisco de Sá Carneiro. Its airport code comes from its home in Porto and its alternate English spelling: Oporto.
Originally opened in 1979, Örebro Airport is located 10km from the city of Örebro in Sweden.
Before the airport was renamed after Medal of Honor recipient Edward O’Hare in 1949, it was known as Orchard Field Airport.
When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. Norfolk, then, used the next letters in its name to make ORF.

The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. With ORC (and other OR- codes) already taken, Worcester opted for ORH.
Located in the village of Ballygarvan, Cork Airport is one of the three primary airports in Ireland. Its airport code comes from the city of Cork.
Once named Villeneuve-Orly Airport, France’s second busiest airport is partially located in both Paris communes Villeneuve-le-Roi and Orly.
Norway’s busiest airport is actually located in Gardermoen, but its airport code honors the capital city of Oslo.
Ostend-Bruges International serves mainly as a cargo and charter airport. Its airport code honors its coastal home city of OSTend.
Bucharest’s airport honors Henri Coandă, inventor of the first jet engine and discoverer of the Coandă effect in fluid dynamics. Its airport code comes from the nearby city of Otopeni.
Built in the 1960s, Ouagadougou International gets its three-letter airport code from the capital of Burkina Faso, Ouagadougou.
Oulu Airport is Finland’s second busiest airport and its airport code reflects its home in the city of Oulu.
Opened in 1957, Novosibirsk Tolmachevo Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of Novosibirsk.
Opened in 1968, Asturias Airport serves the principality of Asturias and gets its three-letter code from its capital city of Oviedo.
Guinea-Bissau’s only international airport gets its three-letter code from its name, Osvaldo Viera International, plus the city of Bissau, plus a filler ‘X’ in between.
Established in 1935, London Oxford Airport was renamed in 2009 to highlight its “proximity” to London (though located 59 miles away). It is located near Kidlington and serves the city of Oxford.
Also known as Paine Field, the airport is adjacent to the Boeing assembly plant that churns out 747s, 777s, and DreamLiners.

Started as an airfield in the 1940s, Toussaint L'Ouverture Airport has had many names, but is currently named after the leader of the Haitian Revolution. Located in the town of Tabarre, it serves the capital city of Port-au-Prince.
Located at the former Plattsburgh Air Force Base, Plattsburgh International took over traffice from Clinton County Airport in 2007. Its airport code comes from the city of Plattsburgh.
Originally built in 1968 to serve the Indian Armed Forces, Paro Airport is the only international airport in the country. Its airport code comes from the district of Paro, Bhutan.
Originally opened in 1936 and named Morrison Field, Palm Beach International was renamed in 1948, with a stint as Palm Beach Air Force Base from 1951-1962.

Johan Adolf Pengel International is named after the former Suriname Prime Minister. While located in the village of Zanderij, its airport code uses rearranged letters from the capitl city of Paramaribo.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Capitán FAP David Abensur Rengifo
Airport_description: Serving the Ucayali Region of Peru, David Abensur Rengifo International gets its three-letter code from its home city of Pucallpa.
Minangkabau International is named after the Minangkabau, the indigenous people of West Sumatra. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Padang.

Inaugurated in 1969, João Paulo II Airport was renamed in 1995 to honor the 1991 visit of Pope John Paul II to the Azores. Located on the island of São Miguel, its airport code honors the city of Ponta Delgada.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Capitán de Corbeta Carlos A. Curbelo
Airport_description: Commonly called Laguna del Sauce Airport, Carlos A. Curbelo International serves the city of Punta del Este and is located in Piriápolis.
Often called Krumovo Airport, Plovdiv Airport primarily serves visitors to the ski resort towns of Bansko and Pamporovo.
Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. PD (Portland) became PDX.
Located in the village of Bolshoye Savino, Perm International gets its airport code from an alternate English spelling of Perm, Perem.
Boasting the second largest terminal in the world, Beijing’s Capital Airport is near the city’s center. Its airport code comes from an older English spelling of Beijing: Peking.
Padre Aldamiz International primarily serves tourists visiting Peru’s national jungle reserves, like the nearby Tambopata-Candamo. Its three-letter code comes from its home in Puerto Maldonado.
Formerly named Bayan Lepas International, Penang International is located in the Bayan Lepas district in Penang, Malaysia.
Known as RAAF Station Guildford during World War II, Perth Airport is now the fourth busiest in Australia and serves the city of Perth.
Renamed in 2012 to honor political and spiritual leader, Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan, Bacha Khan International gets its airport code from its home in the city of Peshawar.
Lauro Kurtz Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of Passo Fundo in Brazil.
Paphos International is the second largest airport in Cyprus and a popular gateway for tourists. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Paphos, alternately spelled Pafos.
Port Harcourt International is located in the suburb of Omagwa and serves the city of Port Harcourt, Nigeria.
Renamed in 1990, Newport News/Williamsburg International was originally named Patrick Henry Airport after Camp Patrick Henry, a former army base. Its code represents Patrick Henry Field.
Palm Beach County Glades Airport has one runway, but no control tower. Its airport code comes from its home city of Pahokee.
During World War II, Philadelphia Municipal Airport served as an Air Force training field. Since 1945, it has been serving Philadelphia and the Delaware Valley.
Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. Phoenix is one where the ‘X’ makes perfect sense.
St. Pete–Clearwater International is named for the two cities it serves. Previously called Pinellas International Airport, but with PIA already taken, it took its code from Pinellas County.
Started as a training airfield in 1934, Glasgow Prestwick Airport claims to be the only place in the U.K. Elvis Presley ever set foot. Its airport code comes from its home in Prestwick.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Capitán FAP Renán Elías Olivera
Airport_description: Primarily used by the Peruvian Army, Renán Elías Olivera Airport gets its three-letter code from its home city of Pisco.
Opened in 1952, the “Greater Pitt” Airport serves and honors the city of Pittsburgh.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Capitán FAP Guillermo Concha Iberico
Airport_description: Guillermo Concha Iberico International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Piura.
Inaugurated in 1982, Pico Airport is located near Madalena on the island of Pico. Its code is completed by the letter ‘X’, often used as a filler letter.

Airport_name: Sultan Syarif Kasim II International Airport
Airport_description: Often referred to as SSK II and named after the last sultan of Siak, Sultan Syarif Kasim II International serves the city of Pekanbaru, Riau, Indonesia.

Beijing’s second international airport follows their first airport (PEK), using the older English name for Beijing: Peking. The ‘X’ may represent nearby Xiong'an New Area or Daxing, but is likely a filler letter.

Airport_name: Sultan Mahmud Badaruddin II International Airport
Airport_description: Named after the last Sultan of Palembang, Sultan Mahmud Badaruddin II Airport serves the city of Palembang, South Sumatra, and surrounding areas.

Palanga International serves the Lithuanian Baltic sea resorts of Palanga, the city of Klaipėda, and parts of Samogitia and western Latvia. Its code is completed by the letter ‘Q’, often used as a filler letter.
Named after Carlos Drummond de Andrade, 20th century Brazilian poet, Belo Horizonte Airport’s three-letter code is made of letters from the neighborhood of Pampulha.
Commonly called Son Sant Joan Airport, Palma de Mallorca Airport gets its airport code from its location in Palma on Mallorca Island.
Inaugurated in 2001, Palmas Airport is named after Lysias Rodrigues of the Brazilian Air Force. Its code is completed by the letter ‘W’, often used as a filler letter.
Located between Noáin and Esquiroz, Pamplona Airport gets its three-letter code from the famous city of Pamplona.
Formerly known as Pochentong Airport, Phnom Penh International is the largest airport in Cambodia. Its three-letter code comes from its home city of Phnom Penh.
Serving primarily island hopping residents and tourists, Pohnpei International gets its airport code from its home on Pohnpei Island.
Originally built in the 1940s and named Durian River Airport, Supadio International serves the city of Pontianak in West Kalimantan.
Pune airport is named after its home in the city of Pune. Its code is completed by the letter ‘Q’, often used as a filler letter.
In 2011, Pensacola Gulf Coast Regional was renamed to Pensacola International, still serving the city of Pensacola and its surrounding areas.
Petrolina Airport is named after former Senator Nilo de Sousa Coelho. Its three-letter code comes from the cities it serves: Petrolina and Juazeiro.

Originally São João Federal Airport, Salgado Filho International was renamed in 1951 in honor of Senator and Minister Joaquim Pedro Salgado Filho. Its airport code comes from the city of Porto Alegre.
Jacksons International is the busiest airport in Papua New Guinea. It is located just outside the city of Port Moresby and is often referred to as Port Moresby Airport.
Poços de Caldas Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of Poços de Caldas.
Opened in 1931, Piarco International is located in the town of Piarco, but serves the capital city of Port of Spain.
Also known as Tafuna Airport, Pago Pago is the largest of the three airports of American Samoa, a small unincorporated territory of the United States located in the south Pacific Ocean.
Fa'a'ā International serves the island of Tahiti in French Polynesia. It is located in the commune of Fa'a'ā in the city of Pape'ete.

Airport_name: Sân bay quốc tế Phú Quôc
Airport_description: Phu Quoc International opened in 2012 and replaced the previous Phu Quoc Airport. Its three-letter code honors its home on the island of Phu Quoc.
In 2012, Prague Ruzyně International was renamed to honor Václav Havel, the Czech Republic’s first president. Its airport code honors its home in the capital city of Prague.
Opened in 1965, Pristina International is named after Adem Jashari, leader of the Kosovo Liberation Army. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Pristina.
Pisa International was formerly named Galileo Galilei Airport in honor of the Italian astronomer. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Pisa.
The US Navy built Naval Air Station Pasco during World War II. After the war, the Navy sold the field to the city of Pasco and it was redeveloped into Tri-Cities Airport.

Built in 1939, Mercedita Airport gets its name from Hacienda Mercedita, the sugar plantation where it was located. Its airport code comes from the city of Ponce, with the ‘S’ as a phonetic substitute for the ‘C’.
Well known for its Sonny Bono Concourse named after the late entertainer, Palm Springs International has been called one of America’s “Most Stress-Free Airports.”
Oakland County International serves Oakland County from Waterford Township. Its airport code comes from a previous name, Pontiac-Oakland Airport.
Located in Abymes, Pointe-à-Pitre Le Raizet Airport serves the city of Pointe-à-Pitre on the island of Grande-Terre in Guadeloupe, France.
Inaugurated in 1947, Tocumen International gets its name from the nearby Tocumen River. Its airport code comes from its home in Panama City.
Located in the commune of Uzein and named after the Pyrenees Mountains, Pau Pyrénées Airport gets its three-letter code from the commune of Pau, France.
Named after two-time Chilean President, Carlos Ibáñez International is located in the city of Punta Arenas. Its code is completed by the letter ‘Q’, often used as a filler letter.
Opened in 1976, Gimhae International (formerly Kimhae) serves the city of Busan. Its three-letter code comes from the city’s former English spelling, Pusan.

Airport_name: Theodore Francis Green Memorial State Airport
Airport_description: T.F. Green Airport, as it’s called for short, honors former Rhode Island governor Theodore F. Green. Actually located in the nearby city of Warwick, its airport code reflects the major city it serves: Providence.
Shanghai Pudong International opened in 1999. Its airport code comes from the Shanghai district of Pudong with a filler ‘V’ replacing the ‘U’ to get PVG.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Lic. Gustavo Díaz Ordaz
Airport_description: PVR is named after Mexican president Gustavo Díaz Ordaz and serves the city of Puerto Vallarta.
The second busiest airport in the state, Provo Municipal serves passengers to three other airports: PHX, OAK, and LAX. Its airport code comes from its home city of Provo, Utah.

Chicago Executive Airport was formerly called Palwaukee Municipal Airport, for its location near the intersection of Palatine Road and Milwaukee Avenue. Located in the northwest suburbs of Chicago, it is the fourth-busiest airport in Illinois.
The airport serving the original Portland (in Maine) started as small Stroudwater Field, later renamed to Portland-Westbrook Municipal Airport.
Built in 1959, Porto Santo Airport was the first airport in the Madeira Islands. Its airport code comes from its home in Porto Santo, plus a helpful ‘X’ as a filler letter.

Previously a military air base and developed into a civilian airport in 1975, Pleiku Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in Pleiku. Its code is completed by an ‘X’, often used as a filler letter.

Airport_name: Manuel Carlos Piar Guayana International Airport
Airport_description: Ciudad Guayana’s airport is named after Manuel Piar, general during the Venezuelan War of Independence. Its airport code is a mix of letters from its home in the city of Puerto Ordaz.
Querétaro Intercontinental replaced Ing. Fernando Espinoza Gutiérrez International Airport in 2004. Its airport code comes from the city of Querétaro.
Opened in 2005 and renamed in 2012, Nelson Mandela International gets its airport code from its home in the capital city of Praia.
Marrakesh Menara Airport gets part of its name from the nearby Menara Gardens and the other part from its home in the capital city of Marrakesh.
While actually located in Salé, Rabat–Salé Airport gets its airport code from the Moroccan capital city of Rabat.
Dallas Executive Airport serves the city of Dallas for general aviation and is a reliever airport for Dallas Love Field. Its airport code comes from its former name, Redbird Airport.
Originally Redding Army Airfield, Redding Municipal was a favorite for military airshows because of the nearby Shasta Lake. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Redding.
Opened in 1943, Raleigh-Durham International is located in Wake County in between the cities of Raleigh and Durham.
Recife International’s full name honors the Battle of Guararapes during the Dutch-Portuguese War and Brazilian sociologist Gilberto Freyre. Its airport code honors its home in Recife.
With a new terminal inaugurated in 2006, Siem Reap International gets its airport code from its home in the city of Siem Reap, Cambodia.
Started in 1917 as Camp Grant, Chicago Rockford International achieved international status in 2004. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Rockford.
Built in 1965, Rangiroa Airport serves the atoll of Rangiroa and French Polynesia.
Located in the township of Mingaladon, Myanmar’s primary international airport serves the city of Yangon. Its airport code comes from an English spelling of Yangon: Rangoon.
Originally dedicated in 1927 as Richard Evelyn Byrd Flying Field, Richmond International Airport is the busiest airport in central Virginia.
Established as Alessandro Flying Training Field in 1918, March Air Reserve Base is named after aviator Peyton C. March, Jr. Its three-letter code honors its home near the city of Riverside.
With the airport code RIV already taken by March Air Force Base in Riverside, California, Riverton Regional took its code from Riverton and switched a ‘W‘ for the ‘V’.

Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Riga International was built relatively recently in 1973, so its airport code comes from Riga plus that helpful ‘X’.
Built in 2003, Logroño-Agoncillo Airport is located in the city of Logroño. Its airport code comes from the nearby village of Recajo in La Rioja.
Rostock–Laage Airport was built in the late 1970s and was originally a National People’s Army facility. Its airport code honors the city of Rostock and the town of Laage.
Ramstein Air Base is a United States Air Force Base located near the city of Kaiserslautern and gets its airport code from the town of Ramstein-Miesenbach.
Built in 1929 as Hubbard Field, Reno–Tahoe International get its three-letter airport code from its home in Reno, Nevada.
Originally opened in 1933, Rennes–Saint-Jacques Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Rennes.
On the shore of Lake Washington, Renton has been the departure point for every brand new Boeing 737 ever made.
Roanoke-Blacksburg Regional is also known as Woodrum Field after former U.S. Representative Clifton A. Woodrum. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Roanoke.
Starting out as Britton Field in 1927, Greater Rochester International Airport serves the city it is named after and its surrounding counties.
Formerly Palau International, Roman Tmetuchl Airport is now named after political leader Roman Tmetuchl. While it serves Melekeok, it is actually located closer to Koror.
Rosario – Islas Malvinas International’s name reflects Argentina’s claim of sovereignty over the Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas). Its airport code reflects its home in the city of Rosario.
Originally built in 1925, Rostov-on-Don Airport became an international hub in 1986. Its airport code honors its home near the city of Rostov-on-Don.
Previously named Walker Air Force Base after Medal of Honor winner General Kenneth Walker, Roswell Air Center serves the city of Roswell and is near the location of the 1947 Roswell crash.
Formerly known as Mana Airport, Swami Vivekananda International was renamed in 2012 to honor the well-known Indian saint. Its airport code honors the city it serves: Raipur.

Inaugurated as Plaine Corail Airport in 1972, it was renamed in 2007 in honor of Sir Charles Gaëtan Duval for his economic contributions. The only daily flights are between the islands of Mauritius and Rodrigues.
The original Rochester Airport was built in 1928 by the Mayo Foundation. Later renamed to Lobb Field, the airport was closed in 1961 and replaced by the current Rochester International.
Renamed “International” in 1993, Fort Myers’ airport was originally regional only. It takes its airport code from Regional Southwest.

Opened in 1956, Rotterdam Airport was the Netherlands’ second national airport and was built in part to replace Waalhaven Airport, destroyed during World War II. Its code comes from the city of Rotterdam.
King Khalid International is named after the former Saudi Arabian king who ruled from 1975 to 1982. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Riyadh, with a ‘U’ as a filler letter.

Airport_name: Aéroport de la Réunion Roland Garros
Airport_description: Roland Garros Airport is named after Roland Garros, French aviator and World War I pilot. It serves Saint-Denis, but gets its airport code from the French island of Réunion.
Rovaniemi airport, the official airport of Santa Claus, is the third busiest airport in Finland.
Opened in 2007, Moss Airport, Rygge is actually located in the town of Moss, but gets its three-letter code from the nearby city of Rygge.
Shaikh Zayed International is named after Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan who helped finance the airport’s construction. Its three-letter code honors its home city of Rahim Yar Khan.
Rzeszów–Jasionka Airport is located in southeastern Poland. Although situated in the village of Jasionka, its airport code comes from the nearby city it serves: Rzeszów.
The only airport on the Caribbean island of Saba, Juancho E. Yrausquin Airport has the shortest commercial runway in the world at only 396 meters.
Santa Fe Municipal features three runways and serves the city of Santa Fe, New Mexico.
Sana'a International is currently closed due to severe damage sustained by its only runway. Its airport code comes from two of its aliases, Sana'a International and El Rahaba Airport.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Monseñor Óscar Arnulfo Romero
Airport_description: Renamed in 2014, Monseñor Óscar Arnulfo Romero International honors Óscar Romero, the fourth Archbishop of San Salvador. It was previously named and is still called Comalapa Airport.
Following Charles Lindbergh’s historic flight, the city where his plane was built capitalized on public support to build its own airport. Its airport code comes from the city it serves, San Diego.
The gateway for south central Texas, San Antonio International was originally known as Alamo Field. Its airport code honors its home in the city of San Antonio, Texas.
Despite having “International” in its name, Savannah/Hilton Head airport has no scheduled commercial flights outside the U.S. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Savannah.
Sabiha Gökçen International is named after the first woman combat pilot in Turkey. Its airport code comes from Sabiha’s name, plus a letter ‘W’, often used as a filler letter.
Built on a former cow pasture, Santa Barbara Municipal gets its airport code from its home in the Santa Barbara/Goleta metropolitan area.
San Bernardino International is located on the former site of Norton Air Force Base and serves the city of San Bernardino.
Opened in 1933 as Bendix Field, South Bend International was once called Michiana Regional (a combination of Michigan and Indiana). Its airport code honors its home in South Bend.

Airport_name: San Luis Obispo County Regional Airport
Airport_description: Opened in 1939 by Earl Thomson, San Luis Obispo County Regional gets its airport code from its home in San Luis Obispo.
Built in the 1950s, University Park Airport is now owned by Penn State University. Its airport code comes from its home near the town of State College.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Comodoro Arturo Merino Benítez
Airport_description: Often called “Pudahuel Airport”, Comodoro Arturo Merino Benítez International honors the founder of the Chilean Air Force. Its airport code honors its home in Santiago, Chile.
Aktau Airport began operations in 1993 and now serves the city of Aktau. Its three-letter code comes from Aktau’s former name, Shevchenko. The airport was previously named Shevchenko-Central.

Airport_name: Aeroporto Internacional de Santiago de Compostela
Airport_description: Santiago de Compostela Airport’s first flight took off in 1937. Its airport code comes from its home near Santiago de Compostela, plus a ‘Q’ as a filler letter.
Socotra Airport is Yemen’s most remote airport, serving the city of Hadibu on the island of Socotra.
Before being renamed in 1995, Louisville International was known as Standiford Field, honoring former state senator Elisha David Standiford.
Opened in 1959, Las Américas International is located in Punta Caucedo. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Santo Domingo, plus a helpful ‘Q’ as a filler letter.
Started as an airfield in 1953, Santander Airport is named after professional golfer Seve Ballesteros and serves the community of Santander.
Originally known as Calabouço Airport, Santos Dumont Airport was inaugurated in 1936 and was named after Brazilian aviator Alberto Santos-Dumont.
“Sea-Tac” was once renamed after U.S. Senator Henry M. Jackson for a short while, but Seattle and Tacoma residents voted to keep their cities in the airport’s name.
Serving London and its surrounding areas, London Southend Airport is situated between the towns of Southend and Rochford.
Sembach Kaserne is a United States Army installation in Sembach, Germany. Its airport code comes from its former name as Sembach Annex.
Used as a military airfield during World War II, Sfax-Thyna International gets its airport code from the nearby city of Sfax.
Kangerlussuaq Airport is a former U.S. military base and today serves as the international gateway for the majority of travel to and from Greenland. Its former name was Sondrestromfjord Air Base.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto de Santa Fe - Sauce Viejo
Airport_description: Sauce Viejo Airport gets its airport code from rearranged letters from the city name of Santa Fe.
Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. San Francisco instead used its last letter ‘O’.
Surgut International, also known as Surgut North, gets its three-letter airport code from its home in Surgut City.
Opened as Springfield–Greene County Airport in July 1945, Springfield–Branson National is a public airport and has non-stop service to twelve U.S. cities.

Airport_name: Sân bay Quốc tế Tân Sơn Nhất
Airport_description: Tan Son Nhat International is named for the township in which it’s located, but serves Ho Chi Minh City. Its airport code comes from Ho Chi Minh City’s former name: Saigon.
Opened in 2011, St. George Regional replaced the landlocked St. George Municipal Airport. Its three-letter code honors the city of St. George, Utah.
Skagway, originally Skagua in Tlingit for “windy place”, was the largest city in Alaska by 1898 because of the Yukon gold rush. Its airport’s code honors its home in Skagway.
Shanghai Hongqiao International was the first airport built in Shanghai. Its airport code makes sense as Shanghai Hongqiao Airport, but comes from the city of SHAnghai.
Located in Weyers Cave near the city of Staunton, Shenandoah Valley Regional is a general aviation airport and serves one commercial airliner.
Shenyang Taoxian International serves Shenyang, capital of Liaoning province.
Operational since 1931, Shreveport Regional Airport’s code honors its home in the city of Shreveport.
Built in 1939, Amílcar Cabral International is named after a Cape Verdean revoluntionary leader. It serves the city of Espargos, but gets its airport code from its home on Sal Island.
Often called just Changi Airport, Singapore’s main airport was named Skytrax “Best Airport in the World” three years in a row.

Since the annexation of Crimea by Russia, the Simferopol International Airport only operates Russian domestic flights, despite the name. Under Russian control, it has been renovated, two new terminals were opened, and passenger traffic has seen substantial increase.
Sion Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home city of Sion and the Rhone Valley where it’s located.

Airport_name: Norman Y. Mineta San Jose International Airport
Airport_description: In 2001, San Jose International was renamed to honor former mayor Norman Mineta. Its airport code honors its home in San Jose, California.

Airport_address: San José del Cabo BS Mexico
Airport_description: Los Cabos International is most known for serving the resort city of Cabo San Lucas, but gets its airport code from its home in the city of San José del Cabo.

Opened in 1969, Sarajevo International is located in the suburb of Butmir and is often called Butmir Airport. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Sarajevo, with a second ‘J’ as a filler letter.

Airport_name: Aeroporto de São José dos Campos-Professor Urbano Ernesto Stumpf
Airport_address: São José dos Campos SP Brazil
Airport_description: Named after Urbano Ernesto Stumpf, aviator and innovator, São José dos Campos Airport gets its airport code from the city of São José dos Campos. The ‘K’ is a phonetic replacement for the ‘C’ in Campos.
Juan Santamaría International honors Juan Santamaría, national hero of Costa Rica who was killed in the Second Battle of Rivas in 1856. Its code comes from the city it serves, San JOsé
Luis Muñoz Marín International is named for Puerto Rico’s first democratically elected governor. Although actually located in Carolina, its airport code reflects the capital city of San Juan.
São Jorge Airport is located in the town of Velas on the island of São Jorge. The ‘Z’ in its code could be from Azores, but is likely a filler letter.
Robert L. Bradshaw International is named after the first Premier of Saint Kitts and Nevis. Its airport code comes from its location on the island of Saint Kitts in the city of Basseterre.
Opened in 1930, Thessaloniki International is often called Macedonia Airport. Its three-letter code comes from an alternate name for the city of Thessaloniki: Salonika, Greece.
Skopje Airport is located in the village of Petrovec and serves the capital city of Skopje.
Sukkur Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Sukkur. It is completed by a ‘Z’, often used as a filler letter.
Originally named Woodward Field after local aviator John P. Woodward, Utah’s busiest airport now gets its name and airport code from state capital Salt Lake City.
Built during the 1940’s, Adirondack Regional was previously named Saranac Lake Airport and serves travelers to the Adirondack Mountains.
Often called just Matacán Airport, this airport in Castile and León gets its three-letter code from its home in the province of Salamanca.
Salina Regional is located at the continental center of the United States, earning it the nickname “America’s Fuel Stop.” Its airport code honors its home in Salina.
George F. L. Charles Airport is named after the country’s former Chief Minister. Serving the city of Castries, it gets its airport code from Saint Lucia.
Formerly named Tirirical Airport, Marechal Cunha Machado International gets its airport code from its home in the city of São Luís, Brazil.
Inaugurated in 1945, Santa Maria Airport is located on the island of Santa Maria and serves the city of Vila do Porto.

When Sacramento International was built, the airport code SAC was already taken by (then named) Sacramento Municipal Airport. So it took its code from its original name, Sacramento Metropolitan Field.
In 1979, Orange County Airport was renamed to honor John Wayne, legendary actor and resident of nearby Newport Beach. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Santa Ana.
After World War II, Shannon Airport became the primary gateway for transatlantic flights to and from the U.S. Its airport code honors its home in the town of Shannon.
Publicly opened in 1991, Hévíz-Balaton Airport is located on the fields of Zalavár and Sármellék and neighbors Lake Balaton. Its airport code stands for Sármellék on Balaton.
Adisumarmo International honors Adisumarmo Wiryokusumo, national hero and pioneer of the Indonesian Air Force. It serves the city of Surakarta, also known as Solo City.
Often called Sofia-Vrazhdebna Airport, Bulgaria’s primary airport gets its three-letter code from its home in Sofia.

Often called simply Sorong Airport, Domine Edward Osok Airport replaced Jefman Airport, a former World War II airfield. Its airport code comes from the city of Sorong plus a ‘Q’, often used as a filler letter.
Located in the Borough of Eastleigh, Southampton Airport was the site for the first Supermarine Spitfire test flight in 1936. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Southampton.
Scotland’s Stronsay Airport gets its three-letter code from its home on Stronsay in the Orkney Islands.
Opened in 1928, the airport is named after Navy Lieutenant James Albert Whitted, one of the first 250 Naval Aviators. Its airport code honors its home city, Saint Petersburg.

Formerly Resnik Airport, Split Airport gets its first two letters from the city it serves, Split. The ‘U’ isn’t as clear, but could come from “Salonae Palatium”, long-believed (erroneously) to be the origin of the city’s name.

Opened during World War I and originally named San Carlos Flying Field, SQL is often misattributed as a reference to the nearby database company, Oracle. It actually stands for San Carlos plus a helpful filler ‘Q’.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Juana Azurduy de Padilla
Airport_description: Juana Azurduy de Padilla International is named after the 19th century guerrilla military leader. Its airport code comes from its home city of Sucre.

Once a military airbase for the Armed Forces of Indonesia, Ahmad Yani International serves Semarang and its surrounding areas. It honors General Ahmad Yani, a major figure in the Indonesian National Revolution.

Sarasota–Bradenton Airport’s first three-letter code was SSO for Sarasota. Because it could easily be confused for the distress signal SOS, the IATA assigned Sarasota SRQ, with the ‘Q’ as a filler letter.

Airport_name: Aeroporto Internacional de Salvador-Deputado Luís Eduardo Magalhães
Airport_description: Named after Brazilian politician Luís Eduardo Magalhães, Salvador Aiport gets its three-letter code from the city of Salvador’s former name of São Salvador.
Stinson Municipal was established in 1915 by aviators and teachers Katherine, Eddie, and Marjorie Stinson. Its airport code comes from its original name and purpose as Stinson School of Flying.
Formerly Saint Isabel Airport, Malabo Airport is one of three paved airports in the country. Its three-letter code comes from Equatorial Guinea’s former history as the colony of Spanish Guinea.
Originally opened in 1968 as an Israeli Air Force Base, Sharm el-Sheikh International gets its airport code from its home city of Sharm el-Sheikh.

Airport_address: Santiago de los Caballeros Dominican Republic
Airport_description: Inaugurated in 2002, Cibao International serves the Cibao region of Dominican Republic. Its airport code comes from its home city of Santiago de los Caballeros.
Lambert-St. Louis International is named after Albert Bond Lambert, Olympic golfer and the first to receive a pilot’s license in the city of St. Louis.
Started as an airfield during World War II, London Stansted Airport opened its first commercial terminal building in 1969 and is a base for many major European low-cost carriers.
Built in 1927, Holman Field was named after airline and stunt pilot Charles W. Holman. Today, the airport is known as the St. Paul Downtown Airport.
Stuttgart Airport was renamed in 2014 to honor former mayor Manfred Rommel. It is the sixth busiest airport in Germany and serves the city of Stuttgart.

Airport_name: Charles M. Schulz - Sonoma County Airport
Airport_description: In 2000, Charles M. Schulz Airport was renamed to honor the famed “Peanuts” cartoonist, a longtime resident of Sonoma County. The airport’s code recognizes the city in which it is located, Santa Rosa.

Previously named after Harry S. Truman, Cyril E. King Airport was renamed in 1984 to honor the former governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands. Its airport code comes from its home on the island of St. Thomas.
Henry E. Rohlsen Airport is named after Henry E. Rohlsen, a Tuskegee Airman during World War II. Its three-letter code honors its home on the island of St. Croix.

Juanda International is the second-busiest airport in Indonesia. It is named after the last Indonesian Prime Minister, Djuanda Kartawidjaja, but gets its airport code from the city it serves: Surabaya.
Friedman Memorial is named after the Friedman family who donated the land to the city of Hailey in 1931. Its airport code comes from the nearby resort community it serves: Sun Valley.
Nausori International is located in the town of Nausori on the island of Viti Levu. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Fiji, Suva.
Sioux City petitioned twice to have its airport code SUX changed. With no great alternatives, they stuck with it and now use the slogan “Fly SUX.”

Airport_address: Kingstown Saint Vincent and the Grenadines
Airport_description: E. T. Joshua Airport is named after Ebenezer Theodore Joshua, the first chief minister of Saint Vincent. Formerly known as Arnos Vale Airport, its three-letter code comes from its location on Saint Vincent Island.
Opened in 1937, Stavanger Airport is the second oldest in Norway. Located in Sola, it gets its airport code from the nearby city of Stavanger.
Opened in 1959, Sheremetyevo International is located in the city of Khimki, but was named after the nearby village of Sheremetyevsky.
Seville Airport, also known as San Pablo Airport, began commercial flights in 1919. Its airport code comes from the city of Seville, plus a ‘Q’ as a filler letter.

Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Koltsovo International serves Yekaterinburg, industrial and cultural center of the Ural region. It was previously named Sverdlovsk, plus that helpful ‘X’.
Founded in the 1930s, Stewart International gets its name from the Stewart family who donated the land for the future airport. It was previously the location for Stewart Dairy Farm.

Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Actually located in the village of Entzheim, this airport gets its code from the town of Strasbourg plus that helpful ‘X’.
Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. This Berlin airport get its code from its home in the town of Schönefeld plus that helpful ‘X’.

Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Princess Juliana International was named after the crowned princess (at the time) of the Netherlands. Its airport code stands for Saint Martin, plus that helpful ‘X’.

Srinagar International is located in the city of Srinagar in Jammu and Kashmir and is known for serving pilgrimage charters to Jeddah. Its airport code is completed with an ‘X’, often used as a filler letter.
Kingsford Smith Airport is named in honor of Sir Charles Kingsford Smith, Australian aviator. Its airport code honors its home in Sydney.
Syracuse Hancock International opened for passenger travel in 1949 and honors Clarence E. Hancock, former New York congressman. Its airport codes honors the city of Syracuse.
Opened in 1994, Sanya Phoenix International gets its name and airport code from its home in the city of Sanya and nearby Phoenix Mountain.
Renovated in 2005, Shiraz International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Shiraz. It is completed with a ‘Y’, often used as a filler letter.

Airport_name: Lapangan Terbang Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah
Airport_description: Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah Airport gave its airport code KUL to Kuala Lumpur International in 1998. Its new code comes from its current and former names: Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah / Subang Airport.
Austria’s second largest airport is named after classical composer Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, but its airport code honors its home in Salzburg.

Shenzhen Bao'an International (formerly Shenzhen Huangtian Airport) gets its three-letter code from the city it serves, Shenzhen, and its location in Bao'an District, historically called Xin'an County.

Renamed in 2011, A.N.R. Robinson International honors Arthur Napoleon Raymond Robinson, the third Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago. Its three-letter code rearranges letters from its home on the island of Tobago.
Takamatsu Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Takamatsu.
Qingdao Liuting Airport will soon be replaced by Qingdao Jiaodong International. Its airport code comes from an older English spelling of Qingdao: Tsingtao.
Tashkent International is the largest airport in Uzbekistan. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of Tashkent.

Dong Tac Airport’s code gets its first letter from its home city of Tuy Hoa. The other two letters come from “Bãi biển”, which translates to “the beach” and represents its close proximity to Vietnam’s coast.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Capitán FAP Pedro Canga Rodríguez
Airport_description: Pedro Canga Rodríguez Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Tumbes, Peru.
Formerly named Novo Alexeyevka International, Georgia’s largest airport is located in the capital city of Tbilisi.
Serving both military and civilian traffic, Tabriz International gets its three-letter code from its home in Tabriz.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Coronel FAP Carlos Ciriani Santa Rosa
Airport_description: Carlos Ciriani Santa Rosa International Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Tacna. It is completed by a ‘Q’, often used as a filler letter.
Lajes Field (or Lajes Air Base) is a multi-use airfield, serving primarily military aircrafts. Its airport code honors its home on the island of Terceira.
Formerly known as Los Rodeos Airport, Tenerife North Airport serves the island of Tenerife. Along with Tenerife South, it brings the most passenger traffic of all the Canary Islands.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto de Tenerife Sur Reina Sofía
Airport_description: Tenerife South Airport was built to accommodate heavy tourist traffic and to relieve Tenerife North which was often covered in trade winds. It opened in 1978 and was dedicated to Queen Sofía of Spain.
The city of Podgorica was known as Titograd from 1946 to 1992, after the Yugoslav leader Josip Broz Tito.
Tingo María Airport’s three-letter code is made of rearranged letters from its home city of Tingo María.
Opened in 1936, Transilvania Târgu Mureș Airport, often called just Transilvania Airport, is located in the village of Vidrasău and serves the city of Târgu Mureș.
A notoriously difficult airport for landing, Toncontín opened in 1933 and gets its three-letter code from the city in which it is located, Tegucigalpa, the capital of Honduras.
Originally opened as an airfield in 1938, Mehrabad International was the primary airport for the city of Tehran until 2007.
Often called Rinas International, Albania’s only international airport is named after Mother Teresa. Its airport code honors the nearby city of Tirana.
