Despite its name, Ta'if Regional does serve international flights. Its airport code honors its home in Ta'if.
Opened in 1951 and sometimes referred to as General Abelardo L. Rodríguez International, its airport code comes from the city of Tijuana.
Formerly Castel Benito airport, Tripoli International was mostly destroyed during the 2014 Libyan Civil War. Traffic has since been diverted to Mitiga International.
Built in 1968 and reconstructed in 1998, Roshchino International gets its airport code from its home city of Tyumen. The ‘J’ comes from the pronunciation of Tyumen, which sounds like Tjumen.
Chuuk International is located on the island of Weno, but gets its airport code from the state of Chuuk, formerly known as Truk. The code is completed by another ‘K’ as a filler letter.
Lennart Meri Airport is named after the second Estonian President, Lennart Meri. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Tallinn.
Toulouse–Blagnac Airport is located in the suburb of Blagnac and gets it airport code from the city of Toulouse.
Renamed in 1973 to honor Israel’s first prime minister, Ben Gurion Airport is often called by its Hebrew acronym, “Natbag.” Its airport code comes from its proximity to the city of Tel Aviv.

Airport_address: São Tomé São Tomé and Príncipe
Airport_description: São Tomé International is a single runway airport and gets its airport code from its home in São Tomé, São Tomé and Príncipe.
Jinan Yaoqiang International is the airport serving Jinan (formerly Romanized as Tsinan), the capital of Shandong Province, China.
Tangier Ibn Battouta Airport is named after Ibn Battouta, Moroccan explorer and scholar. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Tangier.
Sometimes called Villa Las Estrellas Airport, Teniente R. Marsh Airport is the only airport in Antarctica with an IATA designation.
Ivato International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the capital city of Antananarivo.

Originally planned as the largest airport in the world with six runways servicing supersonic jets, Everglades Jetport’s construction was stopped due to environmental concerns. Its name was changed to Dade-Collier Training and Transition Airport.
First opened in 1955, Toledo Express Airport is located in the townships of Swanton and Monclova. Its airport code honors the city it serves: Toledo.
Opened in 1964, Tromsø Airport is located on the western shore of the island of Tromsøya.
Renamed in 1950, Tampa International was once Drew Field Municipal, named after land developer John H. Drew. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Tampa.
Previously named Chiang Kai-shek International after the former president, Taiwan’s largest airport is actually located in Taoyuan City. Its airport code honors the city it serves, Taipei.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Cadete FAP Guillermo del Castillo Paredes
Airport_description: Guillermo del Castillo Paredes Airport gets its three-letter code from its home city of Tarapoto, Peru.
Located in the town of Værnes, Trondheim Airport gets its three-letter code from the city it serves, Trondheim.
Tiree Airport is located just outside of Balemartine and gets its airport code from the island of Tiree.
Opened in 1956, Sandefjord Airport is located in Torp and is often called Torp Flyplass.
Tri-Cities Regional’s airport code honors the Tri-Cities area of NE Tennessee and SW Virginia, including the cities of Bristol, Kingsport, and Johnson City.
Built in 1953 at the site of a former World War II base, Turin Airport is now named after former Italian President Sandro Pertini. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Turin.
Originally Ronchi dei Legionari Airfield in the 1930s, Trieste – Friuli Venezia Giulia Airport serves the city of Trieste.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional Capitán FAP Carlos Martínez de Pinillos
Airport_description: Carlos Martínez de Pinillos International serves the beachtown community of Huanchaco and Peru’s third largest city, Trujillo.
Trivandrum International was upgraded to an international airport in 1991. Located in Thiruvananthapuram, its name and code comes from the city’s short name, Trivandrum.
Built in 1943 by the U.S. Navy as Mullinix Field, Bonriki International gets its three-letter airport code from its location in the atoll of Tarawa.
Built in 1936, Taipei Songshan Airport was originally named Matsuyama Airdrome and served as a Japanese military airbase.
Astana International is located in Astana, which became the capital city of Kazakhstan in 1997. In 1963 when the airport opened, Astana was named Tselinograd.
Tianjin Binhai International is located in Dongli District, Tianjin (alternately Romanized as Tientsin). It is one of the major air cargo centers in the People’s Republic of China.
Previously known as Mercer County Airport, it was renamed in 1995 to Trenton–Mercer Airport to promote its location in the capital city of Trenton.
Renamed ‘International’ in 1963, Tulsa Municipal Airport opened in 1928 and just two years later was the busiest airport in the world, outpacing London, Berlin, and Paris.
Tunis–Carthage International is named after the nearby historic city of Carthage and the city it serves, Tunis.
Tucson International is the second busiest airport in Arizona. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Tucson.
Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. This Berlin airport get its code from its home in the borough of Tegel plus that helpful ‘X’.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Capitán FAP Víctor Montes Arias
Airport_description: Used by the United States Army Air Forces during World War II, Víctor Montes Arias Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of Talara. It is completed with a ‘Y’, used as a filler letter.
Located in the city of Alcoa, south of Knoxville, McGhee Tyson Airport is named after U.S. Navy pilot Charles McGhee Tyson who was lost in action during World War I.
Previously a military airport, Tuzla International reopened in 1998 as a civilian airport. Its three-letter code honors its home in Tuzla.
Ufa International is the primary airport serving Ufa, the capital of the Republic of Bashkortostan in Russia. It is one of the few airport codes that matches the full name of the city it serves.
Phù Cát Airport is located in Phu Cat District, but gets its three-letter code from the city it serves, Qui Nhon.

Mariscal Sucre International is named after Antonio José de Sucre who fought for the independence of Quito, in what is now Ecuador. Because the FCC reserved codes starting with ‘Q’, it opted for other letters from its home city of Quito.

Opened in 1957 as Buyant-Ukhaa Airport, Chinggis Khaan International was renamed in 2005 after Genghis Khan and in honor of the Mongolian state’s 800th anniversary. Its airport code comes from its home city of Ulaanbaatar.
Sultan Hasanuddin International is the busiest airport in South Sulawesi and serves the city of Makassar. Its airport code comes from the city’s former name: Ujung Pandang.
Oral Ak Zhol Airport is located in the city of Oral, also called Uralsk in Russian. The airport was formerly named Uralsk Ak Zhol.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Ushuaia Malvinas Argentinas
Airport_description: Ushuaia International’s full name reflects Argentina’s claim of sovereignty over the Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas). Its airport code reflects its home in the city of Ushuaia.
Samui International opened in 1989 and, except for its gift shop, is entirely outdoors. Its airport code USM is a combination of letters from the island of Ko Samui where it’s located.
Used as Udorn Royal Thai Air Force Base during the Vietnam War, Udon Thani International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Udon Thani.
Now named after Lake Baikal, Baikal International was once named after its home in the city of Ulan-Ude.
Started in 1945 as a military airfield, Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk Airport serves the city of Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk. Its code is completed by a second letter ‘U’, used as a filler letter.

Formerly Beane Army Airfield, Hewanorra International bears the island’s former name of Hewanorra. Two of its code’s letters come from the city of Vieux Fort. The ‘U’ could come from Saint Lucia, but is likely a filler letter.
Developed by Maldivian businessman Qasim Ibrahim, Maamigili’s international airport gets its airport code from its full name: Villa International Airport Maamigili.
Built in 1946 to replace the small Tihina Airport, Varna Airport is located near the town of Aksakovo.
Also known as Lupepau’u  Airport, Vava’u International is a main tourist hub for Tonga, especially during whale migration season. Its three-letter code comes from the city name of Vava’u.

Airport_name: Sân bay Quốc tế Cần Thơ
Airport_description: Built by the U.S. Air Force during the Vietnam War and previously called Tra Noc Airport, Can Tho International opened commercially in 2008. It gets its airport code from its country and city of Vietnam, Can Tho.
Marco Polo Airport shares its name with the famous Venetian merchant traveler. Its airport code comes from its home city of Venice.
Built by the U.S. Navy during the Vietnam War, Chu Lai Airport opened commercially in 2005. It serves Tam Ky, but gets its airport code from its country and city of Vietnam, Chu Lai.
Viracopos/Campinas International Airport is sometimes referred to as São Paulo/Campinas, and is named after the neighborhood where it is located.
Con Dao Airport is located in the archipelago of Con Dao, but gets its three-letter code from its country and island of Vietnam, Con Son Island.
Inaugurated in 1972, El Hierro Airport is located on the island of El Hierro and gets its three-letter code from the nearby city of Valverde.
Dong Hoi Airport gets its three-letter code from its home country and city of Vietnam, Dong Hoi.
Opened in 1954, Vigo Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Vigo.
Originally Sky Haven Airport, North Las Vegas Airport opened December 7, 1941, the same day as the attack on Peark Harbor. In 1968, It was renamed North Las Vegas Air Terminal.
Austria’s largest airport is actually located in the town of Schwechat, but gets its airport code from the nearby capital city of Vienna.

Vinh Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Vinh. The second ‘I’ is a filler letter, but will soon stand for ‘International’ when the airport begins international traffic in 2030.

Airport_name: Aeroporto de Vitória-Eurico de Aguiar Salles
Airport_description: Formerly Goiabeiras Airport, Vitória Airport is named after Eurico de Aguiar Salles, a local politician. Its airport code comes from the city of Vitória. The ‘X’ is a filler letter for ‘C’ from the previously spelled Victória.
Rach Gia Airport gets its three-letter code from its country and province of Vietnam, Kien Giang.
Vnukovo International is Moscow’s oldest operating airport, originally opened in 1941. It received its name and airport code from the small nearby village of Vnukovo.
Spain’s 8th busiest airport is located in the town of Manises, but serves the city of Valencia.
Built during World War II, Bauerfield Airport gets its name from Lt-Col. Harold W. Bauer, a U.S. Marine Corps pilot. Its airport code comes from its alternate name, Port Vila International.
Opened in 1938, Valladolid International is located in the town of Villanubla and serves the city of Valladolid.
Named after the Venezuelan painter, Arturo Michelena International serves the city of Valencia. It is not to be confused with VLC, located in Valencia, Spain.
Opened in 1932, Vilnius International is the largest airport in Lithuania. The city of Vilnius has had many different spellings in various languages including Wilno, Vilna, and Vilno.

Formerly Varanasi International, Lal Bahadur Shastri International was renamed in 2005 to honor India’s second Prime Minister. Its airport code honors one of the holiest of the seven sacred cities, Varanasi.
Van Nuys Airport serves Los Angeles, located in the Van Nuys neighborhood of the San Fernando Valley.
Previously named Gumrak Airport, Volgograd International gets its three-letter code from its home near the city of Volgograd.
Voronezh-Chertovitskoye International gets its three-letter code from the primary city it serves, Voronezh, located 11km south of the airport.
Located within Eglin Air Force Base, Destin–Fort Walton Beach Airport gets its code from the nearby city of Valparaiso, Florida.
Verona Villafranca Airport was originally a military airport during World War I. Today, it serves travelers to and from Verona, the city of Romeo and Juliet.
Wattay International is an international airport in the country of Laos. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Vientiane where it’s located.

Airport_address: Santa Cruz de la Sierra Bolivia
Airport_description: Viru Viru International opened in 1983 and replaced El Trompillo Airport. Its name is derived from the word “Birubiru”, which refers to a now dry nearby river.
Formerly named Okecie International, Warsaw Chopin Airport honors Polish composer Frédéric Chopin. Its airport code honors its home in Warsaw.
Formerly J.G. Strijdom Airport, Namibia’s primary international airport is now named after Hosea Kutako, political leader and national hero. Its airport code comes from its home in Windhoek.
Renamed in 2009, Umbu Mehang Kunda Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of Waingapu on the island of Sumba.
Located in the suburb of Rongotai, New Zealand’s third busiest airport serves its capital city of Wellington.
Opened in 2012, Warsaw–Modlin Mazovia Airport is located in the town of Nowy Dwór Mazowiecki and serves the city of Warsaw.

Airport_name: Port Lotniczy Wrocław im. Mikołaja Kopernika
Airport_description: Wroclaw–Copernicus Airport was renamed in 2005 after the famous astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus. Its airpot code honors its home in the city if Wroclaw.
Sunan Shuofang International serves the cities of Wuxi and Suzhou in Jiangsu Province, China (Sunan means ‘Southern Jiangsu’).
Christmas Island Airport gets its three-letter code from its home on Christmas Island, a territory of Australia. The ‘X’ is likely a filler letter, but is also a common short-hand for Christ (X-mas).
Opened in 1991, Xi'an Xianyang International serves the city of Xi'an, and is located in the Weicheng District of Xianyang.
Xiamen Gaoqi International is the eighth busiest airport in China and is located on the north side of Xiamen Island.

The letter ‘X’ is often used as a filler letter. When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the U.S. Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. So Northwest Arkansas Regional opted to use the ‘X’ as its first letter.
Opened in 1991, Xining Caojiabao Airport is located in Qinghai, China. Its airport code comes from the city of Xininng.

Jerez Airport serves the city of Jerez, famous for the fortified wine, sherry. Its airport code likely comes from a combination of an alternate spelling of Jerez, Xeres, and the English spelling, Sherry.
With a few exceptions, codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. It‘s not confirmed, but some claim the ‘AM’ stands for Airport Marie.
Yap International is one of the few airports whose code is the same as the name of the area it serves, Yap Island.

With a few exceptions, codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Built to protect the coast during World War II, Tofino Airport can be the start or end of the country. Its code, then, is made of the first and last letters of the alphabet, ‘AZ’.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Nanaimo Airport is actually located in the city of Cassidy where it gets the other two letters of its name.
With a few exceptions, codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Opened in 1983, Boundary Bay Airport serves the Vancouver area and is located in the town of Delta.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Edmonton International’s code reflects the city’s military history and comes from the nearby Canadian Forces Base, also called Edmonton Garrison.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘FB’ comes from Frobisher Bay, the region Iqaluit rests on.
Airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. This Manitoba airport gets its other two letters from its home in the city of Gods Lake Narrows.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The other letters likely come from Gjoa Haven and Kitikmeot Region, where the airport is located.

Airport_name: John C. Munro Hamilton International Airport
Airport_description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. ‘HM’ comes from this airport’s home in the city of HaMilton.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Named after former Premier Robert Stanfield, Halifax International’s code is completed by Halifax and a helpful filler letter ‘Z’.
Until 1958, Willow Run was Detroit’s primary airport. Its three-letter code represents the nearby town of Ypsilanti and its nickname’s pronunciation of “Ip-see.”
Samjiyŏn Airport is a military airport and only receives flights from Pyongyang Sunan International. Its three-letter code of YJS comes from rearranged letters from the city of Samjiyŏn.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The northernmost airport in the world gets its other two code letters from its home in the city of Alert.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘LW’ comes from the city’s name: Kelowna. The phrase ‘Your Link to the World’ (a backronym) has been used in the YLW branding to make the code more memorable.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The other letters for YMM come from its home city of Fort McMurray.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Mirabel Airport is primarily a cargo airport near Montreal. The ‘X’ in its code is a filler letter.

Airport_name: Prince Abdul Mohsin bin Abdulaziz Airport
Airport_description: Expanded in 2009, Prince Abdul Moshin bin Abdulaziz Airport is located in the city of Yanbu' Al Bahr in Saudi Arabia.
Originally opened in 1940, Youngstown–Warren Regional is home to Youngstown–Warren Air Reserve Station. It serves the nearby cities of Youngstown and Warren, Ohio.
Reopened in 2013 after resurfacing its runway, Yongphulla Airport serves the city of Trashigang. Its airport code comes from its name and the nearby village of Yongphulla.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. ‘OO’ comes from this airport’s home in the city of Oshawa, Ontario.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Named after two Fathers of Confederation, Macdonald-Cartier International gets its other two letters from its home in Ottawa.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports.  The next two letters come from its home in Québec.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘Q’ is a filler letter and the ‘M’ comes from the city it serves: Moncton (though it’s actually located in Dieppe).
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The other two letters in Regina International’s code come from its home in “The Queen City” of Regina.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘Q’ is a filler letter and the ‘T’ comes from its home in the city of Thunder Bay.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Formerly named Newfoundland Airport, Gander International has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. J.A. Douglas McCurdy Airport in Sydney has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Sudbury Airport serves Greater Sudbury in Ontario.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Saint John Airport’s code is completed with letters from its home city of Saint John.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘TZ’ isn’t as clear, but it’s been said it represents the radio call of the airport’s weather station.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘UL’ isn’t as clear, but may be due to a nearby radio beacon which has continuously broadcast those letters since before the airport’s establishment in 1941.
Yuma International’s aviation history began in 1911 when Robert Fowler set a world record for endurance and distance. Its three-letter code honors its home in the city of Yuma, Arizona.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Vancouver International is actually located in the city of Richmond, but gets its other two letters from the major port city it serves, Vancouver.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. James Armstrong Richardson International honors the Canadian aviator, but its airport code honors its home in Winnipeg.

Airport_name: Saskatoon John G. Diefenbaker International Airport
Airport_description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Saskatoon International has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Medicine Hat Airport has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. London International has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Abbotsford International in British Columbia has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘XY’ isn’t as clear. The ‘Y’ likely stands for Yukon, and it’s said the ‘X’ is a filler letter.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The second ‘Y’ is a filler letter and the ‘C’ comes from its home in the city of Calgary.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Smithers Regional in British Columbia has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Formerly called Patricia Bay Airport, Victoria International has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The second ‘Y’ is a filler letter and the ‘T’ comes from its former name, Torbay Airport. This helps differentiate it from the other Saint John Airport (YSJ).

Most airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘YZ’ is said to be the old railway station code for Malton, an area west of Toronto where the airport is located. You may know YYZ from the song by Canadian rock band Rush.
With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Yellowknife Airport has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.
Zadar Airport formerly served as a Lufthansa flight school but now serves the city of Zadar, Croatia.
Located in the suburb of Pleso and often called Pleso Airport, Croatia’s main international airport gets its code from the capital city of Zagreb.
Zaragoza Airport is home to the Spanish Air Force 15th Group and serves commercial traffic to the city of Zaragoza.

Airport_name: Aeropuerto Internacional General Leobardo C. Ruiz
Airport_description: The city of ZaCatecas is serviced by General Leobardo C. Ruiz International, hence the airport code ZCL.
Built in 1998, Ixtapa-Zihuatanejo International is a gateway for the many tourists of Mexico’s beaches and serves the Ixtapa-Zihuatanejo area.
The busiest tourist airport in the Mexican state of Colima, Playa de Oro International gets its three-letter code from the city of Manzanillo.
Opened in 1961, Queenstown Airport is located in the suburb of Frankton. Its airport code comes from New Zealand, Queenstown.
Not surprisingly, Switzerland’s busiest airport is located in its largest city of Zürich.
